editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ANY THING FOR A QUIET LIFE.
A COMEDY, Formerly Acted at Black-Fryers, by His late Majeſties Servants.
LONDON: Printed by Tho. Johnſon for Francis Kirkman, and Henry Marſh, and are to be ſold at the Princes Arms in Chancery-Lane. 1662.

list.item: George Creſsingham, ſon to Sir Francis.
Franklin a Sea-Captain, ſon to old Franklin, and Companion to George Creſsingham.
Knaves-bee a Lawyer, and Pandor to his Wife▪
Selenger, Page to the Lord Beaufort.
George and Ralph, two Prentices to Water Chamlet.
Fleſh-hook and Counter-buff, a Sergeant and a Yeoman.
Two Children of Sir Francis Creſsinghams, nurs'd by Water Chamlet.
Lady Creſsingham, wife to Sir Francis.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: HOw ere th'intents and appetites of men
Are different as their faces, how and when
T'employ their actions, yet all without ſtrife
Meet in this point, Any thing for a Quiet Life.
Nor is there one I think that's hither come
For his delight, but would finde Peace at home
On any terms. The Lawyer does not ceaſe
To talk himſelf into a ſweat with pain,
And ſo his Fees buy Quiet, 'tis his gain:
The poor man does endure the ſcorching Sun,
And feels no wearineſs his day-labor done,
So his Wife entertain him with a ſmile,
And thank his travail, though ſhe ſlept the while:
This being in men of all conditions true,
Does give our Play a Name; and if to you
It yield Content, and uſual Delight,
For our parts we ſhall ſleep ſecure to night.

div.head: Any thing for a Quiet Life.
ACTUS I.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Beaufort, and Sir Francis Creſſingham.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: AWay, I am aſham'd of your proceedings, and ſeriouſly you have in this one act overthrown the reputation the world held of your wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Can you not ſee your error? that having buried ſo good a wife not a moneth ſince; one that, to ſpeak the truth, had all thoſe excellencies which our books have onely feign'd to make a compleat Wife, moſt exactly in her in practice, and to marry a Girl of fifteen; one bred up i'th Court, that by all conſonancy of reaſon, is like to croſs your eſtate: why, one new Gown of hers when 'tis paid for, will eat you out the keeping of a bountiful Chriſtmas. I am aſham'd of you, for you ſhall make too dear a proof of it, I fear; that in the election of a Wife, as in a project of War, to erre but once, is to be undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Good my Lord, I do beſeech you let your better judgement go along with your reprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So it does, and can finde nought to extenuate your fault, but your dotage: you are a man well ſunck in years, and to graft ſuch a yong bloſſom into your Stock, is the next way to make every carnal eye beſpeak your injury. Troth I pity her too, ſhe was not made to wither and go out by painted fires, that yields her no more heat, then to be lodg'd in ſome bleak Banquetting-houſe i'th dead of Winter, and what follows then? your ſhame, and the ruine of your children, and there's the end of a raſh bargain.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p:
With your pardon, that ſhe is young is true; but that Diſcretion ha's gone beyond her years▪ and overtane thoſe of maturer age, does more improve her goodneſs. I confeſs ſhe was bred at Court, but ſo retiredly, that (as ſtill the beſt in ſome place is to be learnt there) ſo her life did rectifie it ſelf more by the Court Chappel, then by the Office of the Revels: beſt of all vertues are
to be found at Court, and where you meet with writings contrary to this known truth, they are framed by men that never were ſo happy to be planted there to know it: for the difference between her youth and mine, if you will read a Matrons ſober ſtaidneſs in her eye, and all the other grave demeanor fitting the Governeſs of a Houſe, you'l then confeſs there's no diſparity between us.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come, come, you read Enter Mr. Water Chamlet what you would have her to be, not what ſhe is. Oh Mr. Water Chamlet, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I thank your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And what news ſtirring in Cheapſide?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Nothing new there my Lord, but the Standard.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh that's a Monument your wives take great delight in; I do hear you are grown a mighty Purchaſer, I hope ſhortly to finde you a continual reſident upon the North Iſle of the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Where? with the Scotch-men?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No Sir, with the Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Believe it, I am a poor Commoner.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Come, you are warm, and bleſt with a fair Wife.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: There's it, her going brave, has the onely vertue to improve my credit in the Subſidy-book.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But I pray, how thrives your New Plantation of Silkworms, thoſe I ſaw laſt Summer at your garden?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: They are remov'd ſir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Whether?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This winter my wife has remov'd them home to a fair Chamber, where divers Courtiers uſe to come and ſee them, and my wife carries them up; I think ſhortly, what with the ſtore of Viſitants, they'l prove as chargeable to me as the morrow after Simon and Jude, onely excepting the taking down and ſetting up again of my Glaſs-windows.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That a man of your eſtate ſhould be ſo gripple-minded, and repining at his wives bounty!

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: There are no ſuch ridiculous things i'th world, as thoſe love money better then themſelves; for though they have underſtanding to know riches, and a minde to ſeek them, and a wit to finde them, and policy to keep them, and long life to poſſeſs them; yet commonly they have withal ſuch a falſe ſight, ſuch bleard-eyes, all their wealth when it lies before them, does ſeem poverty, and ſuch a one are you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Good ſir Francis, you have had ſore eyes too, you have
been a Gameſter, but you have given it o're, and to redeem the vice belong'd to't, now you entertain certain farcels of ſilenc'd Miniſters, which I think will equally undo you▪ yet ſhould theſe waſte you but lenatively, your deviſing new Water-mill for recovery of drown'd Land, and certain dreams you have in Alchimy to finde the Philoſophers-Stone, will certainly draw you to'th bottom: I ſpeak freely ſir, and would not have you angry, for I love you.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: I am deeply in your Books for furniſhing my late VVedding; have you brought a Note of the particulars?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No ſir, at more leiſure.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: What comes the ſum to?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: For Tiſſue, Cloth of Gold, Velvets and Silks, about fifteen hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Your money is ready.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: And how does my two yong children, whom I have put to board with you?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Have you put forth two of your children already?

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Twas my wifes diſcretion to have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come, tis the firſt principle in a Mother-in-law's Chop-Logick, to divide the Family, to remove from forth your ſight the Object, that her cunning knows would dull her inſinuation: had you been a kinde father, it would have been your practice every day to have preacht to theſe two young ones carefully, your late Wifes Funeral Sermon. L'as poor ſouls, are they turn'd ſo ſoon a graſing?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My Lord, they are plac'd where they ſhall be reſpected as mine own.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I make no queſtion of it, good Mr. Chamlet. See here your eldeſt ſon, Franck Creſsingham!

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: You have diſpleas'd and griev'd your Mother in Law, and till you have made ſubmiſſion and procur'd her pardon, Ile not know you for my ſon.

sp.speaker: George Creſs.
sp.p: I have wrought her no offence ſir, the difference grew about certain Jewels which my Mother (by your conſent) lying upon her Death-bed, bequeath'd to her three Children; theſe I demanded, and being deny'd theſe, thought this ſin of hers to violate ſo gentle a Requeſt of her Predeceſſor, was an ill foregoing of a Mother in Laws harſh nature.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Sir, underſtand my will mov'd in her denial: You have Jewels to pawn, or ſell them! Sirrah, I will have you as obedient to this woman as to my ſelf, till then you are none of mine.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Oh Mr. George, be rul'd, do any thing for a quiet Life, your Fathers peace of Life moves in it too. I have a Wife, when ſhe is in the Sullens, like a Cooks dog that you ſee turn a wheel, ſhe will be ſure to go and hide her ſelf out of the way Dinner and Supper: and in theſe Fits Bowe-bell is a ſtill Organ to her, when we were married firſt, I well remember, her railing did appear but a viſion, till certain ſcratches on my hand and face, aſſur'd me it was ſubſtantial. She's a creature uſes to way lay my faults, and more deſires to finde them out, then to have them amended: She has a Book, which I may truly nominate her Blackbook, for ſhe remembers in it in ſhort Items all my miſdemeanors: As, Item ſuch a day I was got fox'd with fooliſh Metheglin, in the company of certain Welſh Chapmen. Item, ſuch a day being at the Artillery-Garden, one of my neighbors in courteſie to ſalute me with his Muſquet, ſet a fire my Fuſtian and Apes Breeches. Such a day I loſt fifty pound in hugger mugger, at Dice at the Queſt-houſe. Item I lent money to a Sea-Captain, on his bare Confound-him he would pay me again the next morning, and ſuch like; for which ſhe rail'd upon me when I ſhould ſleep, and that's, you know, intollerable; for indeed 'twill tame an Elephant.

sp.speaker: George Creſs.
sp.p: Tis a ſhrewd vexation, but your diſcretion ſir, does bear it out with a moneths ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Yes, and I would wiſh you to follow mine example.

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p: Here's ſmall comfort George from your Father. Here's a Lord whom I have long depended upon for employment, I will ſee if my ſuit will thrive better. Pleaſe your Lordſhip, you know I am a younger brother, and my Fate throwing me upon the late ill-ſtarr'd Voyage to Guiana; failing of our golden hopes, I and my Ship addreſt our ſelves to ſerve the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, I underſtood ſo.

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p: Who gave me both Encouragement and Means, to do him ſome ſmall ſervice 'gainſt the Turk; being ſettled there both in his Pay and Truſt, your Lordſhip minding to rigg forth a Ship to trade for the Eaſt-Indies, ſent for me, and what your promiſe was, if I would leave ſo great a fortune to become your ſervant, your Letters yet can witneſs.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, what follows?

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p:
That for ought I perceive, your former purpoſe is
quite forgotten; I have ſtayed here two moneths, and finde your intended Voyage but a Dream, and the Ship you talk of as imaginary, as that the Aſtronomers point at in the clouds. I have ſpent two thouſand Duckets ſince my arrival; men that have command, my Lord, at Sea, cannot live a ſhore without money.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Know ſir, a late Purchaſe which coſt me a great ſum, has diverted me from my former purpoſe, beſides Suits in Law do every Term ſo trouble me by Land, I have forgot going by Water. If you pleaſe to rank your ſelf among my followers, you ſhall be welcome, and Ile make your means better than any Gentlemans I keep.

sp.speaker: Franklin.
sp.p: Some twenty Mark a year! will that maintain Scarlet and Gold-lace, play at th▪ Ordinary, and Beavers at the Tavern?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I had thought to prefer you to have been Captain of a Ship that's bound for the Red-ſea.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: VVhat hinders it?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why certainly the Merchants are poſſeſt you have been a Pyrate.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Say I were one ſtill, if I were paſt the Line once, why methinks I ſhould do them better ſervice.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Pray forbear: here's a Gentleman whoſe buſineſs muſt ingroſs me wholly.

sp.speaker: George Creſs.
sp.p: What's he, doſt thou know him?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A pox upon him, a very knave and raſcal, that goes a hunting with the penal Statutes; and good for nought but to perſwade their Lords to rack their Rents, and give o're Houſe-keeping; ſuch Caterpillars may hang at their Lords ears, when better men are neglected.

sp.speaker: George Creſs.
sp.p: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Knaves-bee.

sp.speaker: George Creſs.
sp.p: Knaves-bee!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
One that deals in a tenth ſhare about Projections: he and his partners when they have got a Suit once paſt the Seal, will ſo wrangle about partition, and ſometimes they fall to'th eares about it, like your Fencers, that cudgel one another by Patent; you ſhall ſee him ſo terribly bedaſht in a Michaelmas Term coming from Weſtminſter, that you would ſwear he were lighted from a Horſe-race: Hang him, hang him, he's a ſcurvey Informer, has more couzenage in him, then is in five travelling Lotteries. To feed a Kite with the carrion of this Knave when he's dead, and reclaim her, oh ſhe would prove an excellent Hawk for tallon: has
a fair Creature to his Wife too, and a witty rogue it is, and ſome men think this knave will wink at ſmall faults; but honeſt George, what ſhall become of us now?

sp.speaker: George Creſs.
sp.p: 'Faith I am reſolv'd to ſet up my reſt for the Low-Countreys.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To ſerve there?

sp.speaker: G. Creſs.
sp.p: Yes certain.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's thin commons, beſides they have added one day more to'th Week then was in the Creation; Art thou valiant? Art thou valiant, George?

sp.speaker: Geo. Creſs.
sp.p: I may be, and I be put too't.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O never fear that, thou canſt not live two hours after thy Landing without a quarrel. Thou muſt reſolve to fight, or like a Sumner, thou'lt be baſtanado'd at every Townes end. You ſhall have Gallants there as ragged as the Fall o'th Leaf, that live in Holland, where the fineſt Linnen's made, and yet wear ne're a Shirt: Theſe will not onely quarrel with a new-commer when they are drunk, but they will quarrel with any man has means to be drunk afore them: Follow my council, George, thou ſhalt not go o're, wee'l live here i'th City.

sp.speaker: Ceo. Creſs.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How? why, as other Gallants do that feed high, and play copiouſly, yet brag they have but nine pound a year to live on: theſe have wit to turn rich Fools and Gulls into Quarter-days, that bring them in certain payment. I have a Project reflects upon y'on Mercer, Mr. Chamlet, ſhall put us into money.

sp.speaker: George Creſs.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, I will not ſtale it afore-hand, 'tis a new one: Nor cheating amongſt Gallants may ſeem ſtrange, Why a reaching Wit goes currant on th'Exchange.

sp.speaker: Knaves-bee.
sp.p: O my Lord, I remember you and I were Students together at Cambridge; but believe me you went far beyond me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: When I ſtudied there, I had ſo fantaſtical a brain, that like a Phelphare, frighted in winter by a Birding-piece, I could ſetle no where; here and there a little of every ſeveral Art, and away.

sp.speaker: Knaves-bee.
sp.p:
Now my wit, though it were more dull, yet I went ſlowly on, and as divers others, when I could not prove an excellent Scholar by a plodding patience, I attain'd to be a Petty Lawyer; and I thank my dulneſs for't, you may ſtamp in Lead any figure, but in Oyl or Quick-ſilver nothing can be imprinted, for
they keep no certain ſtation.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: O, you tax me well of irreſolution; but ſay worthy friend, how thrives my weighty Suit which I have truſted to your friendly boſom? is there any hope to make me happy?

sp.speaker: Knaves-bee.
sp.p: Tis yet queſtionable, for I have not broke the yce to her; an hour hence come to my houſe, and if it lye in man, be ſure, as the Law Phraſe ſays, I will create you Lord Paramount of your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: O my beſt friend, and one that takes the hardeſt courſe i'th world, to make himſelf ſo. Sir, now Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord, my Wife is coming down.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, I have buſineſs ſo importunes me o'th ſudden, I cannot ſtay; deliver mine excuſe, and in your ear this. Let not a fair woman make you forget your children.

sp.speaker: La. Creſs.
sp.p: What? are you taking leave too?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Yes, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Creſs.
sp.p: The rich Stuff which my Husband bought of you, the works of them are too common: I have got a Dutch Painter to draw Patterns, which Ile have ſent to your Factors; as in Italy, at Florence and Raguſa, where theſe Stuffs are woven, to have pieces made for mine own wearing of a new invention.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: You may Lady, but 'twill be ſomewhat chargeable.

sp.speaker: La. Creſs.
sp.p: Chargeable! what of that? if I live another year, Ile have my Agents ſhall lye for me at Paris, and at Venice, and at Validolet in Spain, for intelligence of all new Faſhions.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Do Sweeteſt, thou deſerv'ſt to be exquiſite in all things.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The two Children to which you are Mother in Law, would be repaired too, 'tis time they had new clothing.

sp.speaker: La. Creſs.
sp.p: I pray fir, do not trouble me with them; they have a Father indulgent and careful of them.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: I am ſorry you made the motion to her.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I have done: He has run himſelf
Into a pretty dotage, Madam, with your leave;
He's ty'd to a new Law, and a new Wife,
Yet to my old Proverb, Any thing for a quiet Life.

sp.speaker: La. Creſs.
sp.p: Good friend, I have a ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: Creſs.
sp.p: Deereſt Self▪ you moſt powerfully ſway me.

sp.speaker: La. Creſs.
sp.p:
That you would give o're this fruitleſs, if I may not ſay this idle, Study of Alchimy; why half your houſe looks like a
Glaſs-houſe.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: And the ſmoke you make is a worſe enemy to good Houſe-keeping, then Tobacco.

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p: Should one of your glaſſes break, it might bring you to a Dead Palſie.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: My Lord, your Quickſilver has made all your more ſolid gold and ſilver flie in fume.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Ile be ruled by you in any thing.

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p: Go Saunder, break all the Glaſſes.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: I flie to't.

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p: Why noble friend, would you finde the true Philoſophers-ſtone indeed, my good Houſwifry ſhould do it. You underſtand I was bred up with a great Courtly Lady, do not think all women minde gay clothes and riot, there are ſome Widows living have improv'd both their own fortunes and their childrens: would you take my counſel, I'de adviſe you to ſell your Land.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: My Land!

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p: Yes, and the Mannor Houſe up n't, tis rotten: Oh the new faſhion'd Buildings brought from the Hague! 'tis ſtately. I have intelligence of a Purchaſe, and the Title ſound, will for half the money you may ſell yours for, bring you in more Rent then yours now yields you.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: If it be ſo good a pennyworth, I need not ſell my Land to purchaſe it, Ile procure money to do it.

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p: Where ſir?

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Why, Ile take it up at Intereſt.

sp.speaker: La Creſſ.
sp.p: Never did any man thrive that purchaſt with uſe-mony.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: How come you to know theſe thrifty Principles?

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p:
How? Why my Father was a Lawyer, and died in the Commiſſion, and may not I by a natural inſtinct, have a reaching that way: there are on mine own knowledge ſome Divines daughters infinitely affected with reading Controverſies, and that ſome think has been a means to bring ſo many Suits into the Spiritual Court. Pray be adviſed, ſell your Land, and purchaſe more: I knew a Pedlar by being Merchant this way, is become Lord of many Mannors: we ſhould look to lengthen our Eſtates Ent. Saunder. as we do our Lives; and though I am young, yet I am confident your able conſtitution of body when you are paſt fourſcore, ſhall keep you freſh till I arrive at the neglected year that I am paſt Childe-bearing, and yet ever there quickning our faint heats in a ſoft embrace, and kindling divine flames in fervent prayers, we
may both go out together, and one Tomb quit our Executors the rites of two.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Oh you are ſo wiſe, and ſo good in every thing, I move by your direction.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: She has caught him!

div.head: ACTUS. II.
div.stage: Enter Knaves-bee and his Wife. Table.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: HAve you drunk the Eggs and Muskadine I ſent you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No, they are too fulſom.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Away, y'are a fool, how ſhall I begin to break the matter to her? I do long, wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Long, ſir!

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Long infinitely. Sit down, there is a penitential motion in me, which if thou wilt but ſecond, I ſhall be one of the happieſt men in Europe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What might that be?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I had laſt night one of the ſtrangeſt Dreams; me thought I was thy Confeſſor, thou mine, and we reveal'd between us privately how often we had wrong'd each others Bed ſince we were married.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Came you drunk to bed? there was a Dream with a witneſs.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No, no witneſs; I dreamt no body heard it but we two. This Dream wife, do I long to put in act, let us confeſs each other, and I vow what ever thou haſt done with that ſweet corps in the way of natural frailty, I proteſt moſt freely I will pardon.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Go ſleep again; was there ever ſuch a motion?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay ſweet woman, and thou wilt not have me run mad with my deſire, be perſwaded to't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well, be it your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But to anſwer truly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O moſt ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Begin then; examine me firſt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why, I know not what to ask you.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Let me ſee, your father was a Captain; Demand of me how many dead Pays I am to anſwer for in the Muſter-book of Wedlock, by the martial fault of borrowing from my neighbors?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Troth I can ask no ſuch fooliſh queſtions

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p:
Why then open Conſeſsion I hope dear wife, will merit freer pardon: I ſinn'd twice with my Laundreſs, and laſt Circuit there was at Banbury a She-chamberlain that had a ſpice of purity,
but at laſt I prevailed over her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O, you are an ungracious husband.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I have made a vow never to ride abroad but in thy company; Oh a little drink makes me clamber like a Monkey: now ſweet wife, you have been an out-lyer too, which is beſt feed in the Foreſt, or in the Purlewes?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A fooliſh minde of you i' this.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay ſweet Love, confeſs freely, I have given you the example.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why you know I went laſt year to Sturbidge-Fair.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And being in Cambridge, a handſom Scholar, one of Emanuel Colledge, fell in love with me.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: O you ſweet-breath'd Monkey.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Go hang, you are ſo boiſterous.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But did this Scholar ſhew thee his Chamber?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: And didſt thou like him?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Like him! oh he had the moſt enticingſt ſtraw-colour'd Beard, a woman with black eyes would have lov'd him like Jeat: he was the fineſt man with a formal wit; and he had a fine dog that ſure was whelpt i'th Colledge, for he underſtood Latine.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Pue wawe, this is nothing, till I know what he did in's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He burnt Wormwood in't, to kill the Fleas i'th Ruſhes.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But what did he to thee there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Some five and twenty years hence I may chance tell you. Fie upon you, what tricks? what crotchets are theſe? have you plac't any body behinde the Arras to hear my Confeſſion? I heard one in England got a Divorce from's wife by ſuch a trick; were I diſpos'd now, I would make you as mad. You ſhall ſee me play the Changling.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No, no wife, you ſhall ſee me play the Changling: hadſt thou confeſt, this other Suit Ile now prefer to thee, would have been diſpatcht in a trice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And what's that ſir?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Thou wilt wonder at it four and twenty years longer then nine days.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would very fain hear it.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: There is a Lord o'th Court, upon my credit a moſt dear, honorable Friend of mine, that muſtlye with thee. Do you laugh? 'tis not come to that, you'l laugh when you know who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Are you ſtark mad?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p:
On my Religion I have paſt my word for't, 'tis the Lord Beaufort, thou art made happy for ever, the generous and bountiful Lord Beaufort: you being both ſo excellent, 'twere pity if ſuch
rare Pieces ſhould not be conferr'd, and ſampled together.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do you mean ſeriouſly?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: As I hope for preferment.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And can you looſe me thus?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Looſe you! I ſhall love you the better: why, what's the viewing any Wardrobe, or Jewel-houſe, without a companion to confer their likings? yet now I view thee well, methinks thou art a rare Monopoly, and great pity one man ſhould enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This is pretty.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Let's divorce our ſelves ſo long, or think I am gone to'th' Indies, or lye with him when I am aſleep, for ſome Familiſts of Amſterdam will tell you may be done with a ſafe conſcience: Come you wanton, what hurt can this do to you? I proteſt nothing ſo much as to keep company with an old woman has ſore eyes: no more wrong then I do my Beaver when I try it thus. Look, this is all; ſmooth, and keeps faſhion ſtill.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are one of the baſeſt fellows.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I lookt for chiding, I do make this a kinde of fortitude the Romans never dreamt of, and 'twere known, I ſhould be ſpoke and writ of when I am rotten, for 'tis beyond example.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But I pray reſolve me: ſuppoſe this done, could you ever love me after?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I proteſt I never thought ſo well of thee, till I knew he took a fancy to thee; like one that has variety of choice meat before him, yet has no ſtomach to 't until he hear another praiſe: Hark, my Lord is coming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Poſſible.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: And my preferment comes along with him; be wiſe, mind your good, and to confute all reaſon in the world which thou canſt urge againſt it when 'tis done, we will be married again wife, which ſome ſay is the onely Superſedeas about Limehouſe, to remove Cuckoldry.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come, are you ready to attend me to the Court?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is this fair one, your wife?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: At your Lordſhips ſervice; I will look up ſome Writings, and return preſently.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: To ſee and the baſe fellow do not leave's alone too!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Tis an excellent habit this, where were you born, Sweet?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am a Suffolk woman, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Believe it, every Countrey you breath on, is the ſweeter for you: Let me ſee your hand. The Caſe is loth to part with the Jewel: Faireſt one, I have skill in Palmeſtry.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good my Lord, what do you finde there?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: In good earneſt I do finde written here, all my good fortune lies in your hand.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You'l keep a very bad Houſe then, you may ſee by the ſmalneſs of the Table.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Who is your Sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sweet-heart!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, come, I muſt ſift you to know it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am a Sieve too courſe for your Lordſhips Manchet.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay, pray you tell me, for I ſee your husband is an unhandſom fellow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh my Lord, I took him by weight, not faſhion: Goldſmiths Wives taught me that way of bargain, and ſome Ladies ſwerve not to follow the example.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But will you not tell me who is your private friend?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes, and you'l tell me who is yours.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Shall I ſhew you her?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes, when will you?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Inſtantly, look you there you may ſee her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ile break the glaſs, 'tis now worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You have made it a flattering one.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I have a Summer-houſe for you; a fine place to flatter ſolitarineſs: will you come and lye there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your husband has promis'd me: will you not?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I muſt wink I tell you, or ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So, Ile kiſs you and wink too,
Midnight is Cupids Holyday.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: By this time 'tis concluded: Will you go my Lord?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I leave with you my beſt wiſhes till I ſee you.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: This now (if I may borrow our Lawyers phraſe) is my Wifes Imparlance, at her next appearance ſhe muſt anſwer your Declaration.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You follow it well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Did I not know my Husband of ſo baſe contemptible nature, I ſhould think 'twere but a trick to try me; but it ſeems they are both in wicked earneſt; and methinks upon the ſudden I have a great minde to loath this ſcurvy unhandſome way my Lord has tane to compaſs me: why 'tis for all the world as if he ſhould come
to ſteal ſome Apricocks my Husband kept for's own Tooth, and climb up upon his head and ſhoulders. Ile go to him, he will put me into brave Clothes, and rich Jewels; 'twere a very ill part in me not to go, his Mercer and his Goldſmith elſe might curſe me; and what Ile do there, a my troth yet I know not; Women though puzzel'd with theſe ſubtile deeds, May, as i'th Spring, pick Phyſick out of weeds.

div.stage: Enter (a Shop being diſcover'd) Walter Chamlet, his Wife Rachel, two Prentices, George and Ralph.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: What iſt you lack, you lack, you lack?
Stuffs for the Belly, or the Back?
Silk-Grograns, Sattins, Velvet fine,
The Roſie-colour'd Carnadine;
Your Nutmeg hue, or Gingerline,
Cloth of Tiſſue, or Tobine,
That like beaten Gold will ſhine
In your Amarous Ladies eyne,
Whileſt you their ſofter Silks do twine: Enter Rachel.
What iſt you lack, you lack, you lack?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I do lack Content Sir, Content I lack: have you or your worſhipful Maſter here, any Content to ſell?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: If Content be a Stuff to be ſold by the Yard, you may have content at home, and never go abroad for't.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Do, cut me three yards, Ile pay for 'em.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: There's all we have i'th Shop; we muſt know what you'l give for 'em firſt.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Why Rachel, ſweet Rachel, my boſom Rachel, how didſt thou get forth? thou wert here ſweet Rac. within this hour, even in my very heart.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Away, or ſtay ſtill, Ile away from thee, one Bed ſhall never hold us both agen, nor one roof cover us: didſt thou bring home

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What iſt you lack, you lack, you lack?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Peace Bandog, Bandog, give me leave to ſpeak, or I'le

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Shall I not follow my Trade? I'm bound to't, and my Maſter bound to bring me up in't.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Peace, good George, give her anger leave, thy Miſtriſs will be quiet preſently.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Quiet! I defie thee and quiet too: Quiet thy Baſtards thou haſt brought home.

sp.speaker: George & Ralph.
sp.p: What iſt you lack, you lack? &c.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Death, give me an Ell, has one bawling Cur rais'd up another? two dogs upon me, and the old Bear-ward will not ſuccour me, I'le ſtave 'em off my ſelf: give me an Ell, I ſay.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Give her not an Inch, Maſter, ſhee'l take two Ells if you do.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Peace George and Ralph, no more words I charge you; and Rachel, ſweet Wife, be more temperate, I know your tongue ſpeaks not by the rule and guidance of your heart, when you proclaim the pretty children of my vertuous and noble Kinſwoman, whom in life you knew above my praiſes reach, to be my baſtards; this is not well, although your Anger did it, pray chide your Anger for it.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Sir, ſir, your gloſs of Kinſwoman cannot ſerve turn, 'tis ſtale, and ſmells too ranck, though your ſhop wares you vent with your deceiving lights, yet your Chamber Stuff ſhall not paſs ſo with me; I ſay, and I will prove.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What iſt you lack?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Why George, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Letcher I ſay, I'le be divorc't from thee, I'le prove 'em thy baſtards, and thou inſufficient.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What ſaid my angry Couſin to you ſir? that we were baſtards?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: I hope ſhe meant not us.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No, no, my pretty Couſins, ſhe meant George and Ralph; rage will ſpeak any thing, but they are ne're the worſe.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes indeed forſooth ſhe ſpoke to us, but chiefly to Ralph, becauſe ſhe knows he has but one ſtone.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: No more of that if you love me, George, this is not the way to keep a quiet houſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I would not for more treaſure then ever I ſaw yet, be in your houſe a cauſe of diſcord.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: And do you think I would, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No indeed, Ned.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Why did you not ſpeak for me with you then, and ſaid we could not have done ſo?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No more ſweet Couſins now: Speak George, Cuſtomers approach.

sp.speaker: Young Creſſ.
sp.p: Is the Barber prepar'd?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: With ignorance enough to go through with it, ſo neer I am to him, we muſt call Couſins, would thou wert as ſure to hit the Taylor.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: If I do not ſteal away handſomly, let me never play the Taylor agen.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What iſt you lack? &c.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Good Sattins ſir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: The beſt in Europe, ſir; here's a piece worth a Piece every yard of him, the King of Naples wears no better Silk; mark his gloſs, he dazles the eye to look upon him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Is he not gum'd?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Gum'd! he has neither mouth nor tooth, how can he be gum'd?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Very pretty.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: An eſpecial good piece of Silk, the Worm never ſpun a finer thread, believe it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Gaſcoyn, you have ſome skill in it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Your Taylor, ſir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: A good piece, ſir; but let's ſee more choice.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Taylor, drive thorow, you know your bribes.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Mum: he beſtows forty pounds, if I ſay the word.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Strike through, there's poundage for you then.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I marry! I like this better, what ſayſt thou, Gaſcoyn?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: A good piece indeed, ſir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: The Great Turk has worſe Sattin at's elbow, then this ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The price?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Look on the mark, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: O. Souſe and P, by my facks, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The beſt ſort then, ſixteen a yard, nothing to be bated.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Fie ſir, fifteen's too high, yet ſo, for how many yards will ſerve for my Sute, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Nine yards, you can have no leſs, Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But I can ſir, if you pleaſe to ſteal leſs; I had but eight in my laſt Sute.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: You pinch us too neer in faith, Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yet can you pinch out a falſe pair of Sleeves to a Freezado Dublet.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No ſir, ſome Purſes and Pin-pillows perhaps: A Taylor pays for his kiſſing that ways.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well ſir, eight yards, eight fifteens I give, and cut it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I cannot truly, ſir.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My Maſter muſt be no Subſidy-man ſir, if he take ſuch fifteens.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I am at higheſt ſir, if you can take money.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Well ſir, I'le give you the buying once, I hope to gain it in your cuſtom: want you nothing elſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not at this time, ſir.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Indeed but you do, Sir Andrew, I muſt needs deliver my Ladies Meſſage to you, ſhe enjoyn'd me by Oath to do it, ſhe commanded me to move you for a New Gown.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sirrah, Ile break your head, if you motion it agen.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: I muſt endanger my ſelf for my Lady, ſir: you know ſhe's to go to my Lady Trenchmores Wedding, and to be ſeen there without a New Gown, ſhe'l have ne're an eye to be ſeen there, for her fingers in 'em: Nay by my fack, ſir, I do not think ſhe'l go, and then the cauſe known, what a diſcredit 't will be to you!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not a word more, Goodman Snip-ſnapper for your ears: What comes this to, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Six pound, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's your money: will you take this, and be gone, and about your buſineſs preſently?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Troth Sir, Ile ſee ſome Stuffs for my Lady firſt, Ile tell her at leaſt I did my good will; a fair piece of Cloth of Silver, pray you now.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Or Cloth of Gold if you pleaſe ſir, as rich as ever the Sophy wore.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are the arranteſt villain of a Taylor, that ever ſat croſs-leg'd: what do you think a Gown of this Stuff will come to?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Why ſay it be forty pound ſir: what's that to you? three thouſand a year I hope will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It will ſir, very good, you were beſt be my Overſeer: ſay I be not furniſht with money, how then?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: A very fine excuſe in you, which place of ten now will you ſend me for a hundred pound, to bring it preſently?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sir, ſir, your Taylor perſwades you well, 'tis for your credit, and the great content of your Lady.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Tis for your content ſir, and my charges: Never think Goodman Falſe-ſtitch to come to the Mercers with me agen; pray will you ſee if my Couſin Sweetball the Barber (he's neereſt hand) be furniſht, and bring me word inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: I flie, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You may flie ſir, you have clipt ſome bodies wings for it to piece out your own; An arrant thief you are.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Indeed he ſpeaks honeſtly and juſtly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You expect ſome gain ſir, there's your cauſe of love.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Surely I do a little, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And what might be the price of this?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This is thirty a yard; but if you'l go to forty, here's a Non pareile.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So, there's a matter of forty pound for a Gown Cloth.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thereabouts, ſir; why ſir, there are far ſhort of your means that wear the like.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do you know my means, ſir?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: By over-hearing your Taylor, ſir, three thouſand a year: but if you'd have a Petticoat for your Lady, here's a ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Are you another Taylor, Sirrah? here's a knave, what are you?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You are ſuch another Gentleman; but for the Stuff Sir, 'tis L. SS. and K; for the turn ſtript a purpoſe, a yard and a quarter broad too, which is the juſt depth of a womans Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And why ſtript for a Petticoat?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Becauſe if they abuſe their Petticoats, there are abuſes ſtript, then 'tis taking them up, and they may be ſtript and whipt too.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Very ingenious.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Then it is likewiſe ſtript ſtanding, between which is diſcover'd the open part, which is now call'd the Placket.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, was it ever call'd otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes: while the word remain'd pure in his original, the Latine tongue, who have no Ks, it was call'd the Placet, a Placendo, A thing, or place, to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Better and worſe ſtill: Now ſir, you come in haſte, what ſays my Couſin?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Proteſt ſir, he's half angry, that either you ſhould think him unfurniſht, or not furniſht for your uſe, there's a hundred pound ready for you; he deſires you to pardon his coming, his folks are buſie, and his wife trimming a Gentleman, but at your firſt approach the money wants but telling.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He would not truſt you with it: I con him thanks, for that he knows what Trade you are of: well ſir, pray cut him patterns, he may in the mean time know my Ladies liking, let your man take the Pieces whole, with the loweſt prices, and walk with me to my Couſins.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: With all my heart, ſir: Ralph, your Cloak, and go with the Gentleman, look you give good meaſure.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Look you carry a good yard with you.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The beſt i'th' ſhop ſir, yet we have none bad: you'l have the Stuff for the Petticoat too?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No ſir, the Gown onely.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: By all means ſir: Not the Petticoat? that were Holy-day upon Working-day yfaith.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are ſo forward for a knave, ſir.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: 'Tis for your credit and my Ladies both, I do it ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Your man is truſty ſir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O ſir, we keep none but thoſe we dare truſt ſir. Ralph, have a care of light gold.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I warrant you ſir, Ile take none.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Come ſirrah: Fare you well ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Pray know my ſhop another time, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That I ſhall ſir, from all the ſhops i'th Town; 'tis the Lamb in Lomberd-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: A good mornings work, ſir; if this Cuſtom would but laſt long, you might ſhut up your ſhop and live privately.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: O George. But here's a grief that takes away all the gains and joy of all my thrift.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What's that, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thy Miſtriſs, George: her frowardneſs ſowres all my comfort.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Alas ſir, they are but Squibs and Crackers, they'l ſoon die; you know her flaſhes of old.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: But they flie ſo neer me, that they burn me; George they are as ill as Muſquets charged with Bullets.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: She has diſcharg'd her ſelf now ſir, you need not fear her.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No man can love without his affliction, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: As you cannot without my Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Right, right, there's harmony in Diſcords: this Lamp of Love while any Oyl is left, can never be extinct, it may (like a ſnuff) wink and ſeem to die, but up he will agen and ſhew his head; I cannot be quiet George, without my wife at home.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And when ſhe's at home, you're never quiet I'm ſure, a fine life you have on't: well ſir, Ile do my beſt to finde her, and bring her back if I can.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Do honeſt George, at Knaves-bee's houſe, that Varlots, there's her haunt and harbour, who enforces a Kinſman on her, and calls him Couſin:
Reſtore her George, to eaſe this heart that's vext,
The beſt new Sute that e're thou wore'ſt is next.

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I thank you afore-hand ſir.

div.stage: Enter Franklin, yong Creſſ. as before, Ralph, Barber, Boy.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p:
Were it of greater moment then you ſpeak of (noble Sir)
I hope you think me ſufficient, and it ſhall be effectually performed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I could wiſh your wife did not know it, Cuz. Womens tongues are not always tuneable, I may many ways requite it.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Believe me, ſhe ſhall not ſir, which will be the hardeſt thing of all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pray you diſpatch him then.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: With the celerity a man tells Gold to him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He hits a good compariſon! give my Waſte-good your Stuffs, and go with my Couſin ſir, he'l preſently diſpatch you.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Come with me youth, I am ready for you in my more private chamber.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sirrah go you ſhew your Lady the Stuffs, and let her chooſe her colour, away, you know whether: Boy, prithee lend me a Bruſh i'th mean time: Do you tarry all day now.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: That I will ſir, and all night too, e're I come agen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here's a Bruſh ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A good childe.

sp.speaker: Barber within.
sp.p: What Toby.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Barber within.
sp.p: Why when, goodman Picklock?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I muſt attend my Maſter, ſir: I come.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do pretty Lad: ſo, take water at Cole-harbor, An eaſie Mercer, and an innocent Barber.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: So friend, Ile now diſpatch you preſently: Boy, reach me my Diſ-membring Inſtrument, and let my Cauterize be ready; and hark you Snipſnap.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: See if my Luxinium, my Fomentation be provided firſt, and get my Rowlers, Bolſters, and Pleggets arm'd.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Nay good ſir diſpatch my buſineſs firſt; I ſhould not ſtay from my ſhop.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: You muſt have a little patience ſir, when you are a Patient; if Prepuſium be not too much periſht, you ſhall looſe but little by it, believe my Art for that.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What's that ſir?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Marry if there be exulceration between Prepuſium and Glannce, by my faith the whole Penis may be endanger'd as far as Os pubes.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What's this you talk on, ſir?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: If they be gangren'd once, Teſticuli, Veſica, and all may run to mortification.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What a pox does this Barber talk on?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p:
O fie youth, Pox is no word of Art, Morbus Gallicus, or Neopolitanus had bin well: Come friend, you muſt not be nice; open
your griefs freely to me.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why ſir, I open my grief to you, I want my money.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Take you no care for that, your worthy Couſin has given me part in hand, and the reſt I know he will upon your recovery, and I dare take his word.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: 's Death, where's my Ware?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Ware! that was well, the word is cleanly, though not artful; your Ware it is that I muſt ſee.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: My Tobine, and Cloth of Tiſſue?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: You will neither have Tiſſue nor Iſſue, if you linger in your malady: better a Member cut off, then endanger the whole Microcoſm.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Barber, you are not mad?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I do begin to fear you are ſubject to Subeth, unkindly ſleeps, which have bred opilations in your brain; take heed, the Simptoma will follow, and this may come to Phrenſie: begin with the firſt cauſe, which is the pain of your Member.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Do you ſee my Yard, Barber?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Now you come to the purpoſe, 'tis that I muſt ſee indeed.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: You ſhall feel it ſir: Death, give me my fifty pounds, or my Ware agen, or I'le meaſure out your Anatomy by the yard.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Boy, my Cauterizing-Iron red hot.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: If you go further, I take my Diſ-membring Knife.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Where's the Knight your Couſin? the Thief, and the Taylor with my Cloth of Gold and Tiſſue?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Gentleman that ſent away his man with the Stuffs, is gone a pretty while ſince, he has carried away our new Bruſh.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: O that Bruſh hurts my hearts ſide: Cheated! cheated! he told me that your Virga had a Burning-feaver.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Pox on your Virga, Barber.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: And that you would be baſhful, and aſham'd to ſhow your head.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I ſhall ſo hereafter, but here it is, you ſee yet my head, my hair, and my wit, and here are my heels that I muſt ſhew to my Maſter, if the Cheaters be not found; and Barber, provide thee Plaiſters, I will break thy head with every Baſon under the Pole.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Cool the Luxinium, and quench the Cauterizer,
I am partly out of my wits, and partly mad:
My Razor's at my heart: theſe ſtorms will make
My Sweet-balls ſtink, my harmleſs Baſons ſhake.

div.head: ACTUS III.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: YOu're welcome Miſtriſs (as I may ſpeak it) but my Lord will give it a ſweeter Emphaſis: Ile give him knowledge of you.

sp.speaker: Mris. Knavesb.
sp.p: Good ſir ſtay, methinks it ſounds ſweeteſt upon your tongue, Ile wiſh you to go no further for my welcome.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Mine! it ſeems you never heard good Muſick, that commend a Bag-pipe: hear his harmony.

sp.speaker: Mris. Kna.
sp.p: Nay good now, let me borrow of your patience, Ile pay you agen before I riſe to morrow, if it pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: What would you forſooth?

sp.speaker: Mris. Kna.
sp.p: Your company ſir.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: My attendance you ſhould have Miſtriſs, but that my Lord expects it, and 'tis his due.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: And muſt be paid upon the hour! that's too ſtrict, any time of the day will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Alas 'tis due every minute, and paid, 'tis due agen, or elſe I forfeit my recognizance, the Cloth I wear of his.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Come, come, pay it double at another time, and 'twil be quitted, I have a little uſe of you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Of me, forſooth, ſmall uſe can be made of me: if you have ſuit to my Lord, none can ſpeak-better for you then you may your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Oh, but I am baſhful.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: So am I in troth, Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Now I remember me, I have a toy to deliver your Lord that's yet unfiniſht, and you may further me, pray you your hands, while I unwinde this Skain of Gold from you, 'twill not detain you long.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You winde me into your ſervice prettily; with all the haſte you can, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: If it tangle not, I ſhall ſoon have done.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: No, it ſhall not tangle if I can help it, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: If it do I can help it, fear not, this thing of long length you ſhall ſee I can bring you to a bottom.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I think ſo too, if it be not bottomleſs, this length will reach it

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p:
It becomes you finely, but I forewarn you, and remember it your enemy gain not this advantage of you, you are his priſoner then; for look you, you are mine now, my captive manacled,
I have your hands in bondage.
sp.stage: graſps the skain between his hands.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: 'Tis a good Leſſon, Miſtriſs, and I am perfect in it, another time I'le take out this, and learn another, pray you releaſe me now.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: I could kiſs you now ſpite of your teeth, if it pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: But you could not, for I could bite you with the ſpite of my teeth, if it pleaſes me.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Well, I'le not tempt you ſo far, I ſhew it but for rudiment.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: When I go a wooing, I'le think on't agen.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: In ſuch an hour I learnt it, ſay I ſhould (in recompence of your hands courteſie) make you a fine Wriſtfavor of this Gold, with all the letters of your Name imboſt on a ſoft Treſs of Hair, which I ſhall cut from mine own Fillet, whoſe ends ſhould meet and cloſe in a faſt True-love-knot, would you wear it for my ſake, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I think not, truly Miſtriſs, my Wriſts have enough of this Gold already, would they were rid on't yet: pray yuo have done, in troth I'm weary.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: And what a vertue is here expreſt in you, which had layn hid but for this tryal; weary of Gold, ſir! Oh that the cloſe Engroſſers of this Treaſure could be ſo free to put it off of hand, what a new mended world would here be! It ſhows a generous condition in you, in ſooth I think I ſhall love you dearly for't.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: But if they were in priſon, as I am, they would be glad to buy their freedom with it.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Surely no, there are that rather then releaſe this dear companion, do lye in priſon with it, yes, and will die in priſon too.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: 'Twere pity but the hangman did enfranchiſe both.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Selenger, where are you?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Eene here, my Lord. Miſtriſs, pray you my liberty, you hinder my duty to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay ſir, one courteſie ſhall ſerve us both at this time; you'r buſie I perceive, when your leiſure next ſerves you I would employ you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You muſt pardon me, my Lord, you ſee I am entangled here: Miſtriſs I proteſt Ile break priſon, if you free me not, take you no notice?

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Oh cry your Honor mercy, you are now at liberty, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
And I'm glad on't, I'le ne're give both my hands at once agen to a womans command, I'le put one finger
in a hole rather.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Free leave have you, my Lord, ſo I think you may have: filthy Beauty, what a white witch thou art!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Lady, y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: I did believe it from your Page, my Lord. Beau. Your husband ſent you to me.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: He did my Lord, with duty and commends unto your Honor, beſeeching you to uſe me very kindly, by the ſame token your Lordſhip gave him grant of a New Leaſe of Threeſcore pounds a year, which he and his ſhould forty years enjoy.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The token's true, and for your ſake Lady, 'tis likely to be better'd, not alone the Leaſe, but the Fee-ſimple may be his and yours.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: I have a ſuit unto your Lordſhip too, only my ſelf concerns.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'T will be granted ſure, tho' it out-value thy husbands.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis ſmall charge, onely your good will, and good word, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The firſt is thine confirm'd, the ſecond then cannot ſtay long behinde.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: I love your Page, ſir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Love him! for what?

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Oh, the great wiſdoms that our Grandſires had! do you ask me reaſon for't? I love him, becauſe I like him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: My Page!

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: In mine eye, hee's a moſt delicate youth, but in my heart a thing that it would bleed for.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Either your eye is blinded, or your remembrance broken: call to minde wherefore you came hither, Lady.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: I do my Lord, for love, and I am in profoundly.

sp.speaker: Beau
sp.p: You trifle ſure, do you long for unripe fruit? 'twill breed diſeaſes in you.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Nothing but worms in my belly, and there's a Seed to expel them; in mellow falling fruit I finde no relliſh.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis true, the youngeſt Vines yields the moſt Cluſters, but the old ever the ſweeteſt Grapes.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: I can taſte of both ſir; but with the old I am the ſooneſt cloid: the green keep ſtill an edge on appetite.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sure you are a common creature.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p:
Did you doubt it, wherefore came I hither elſe? Did you think that honeſty onely had bin immur'd for you, and I ſhould bring it as an Offertorie unto your ſhrine of Luſt? As it was, my Lord, 'twas meant to you, had not the ſlippery Wheel of Fancy turn'd when I beheld your Page; nay had I ſeen another before
him in mine eyes better grace, he had bin fore-ſtal'd; but as it is, (all my ſtrength cannot help) beſeech you your good will, and good word, my Lord, you may command him, ſir; if not affection, yet his body, and I deſire but that, do't, and I'le command my ſelf your proſtitute.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Y'are a baſe ſtrumpet, I ſucceed my Page!

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Oh that's no wonder, my Lord, the ſervant oft taſtes to his Maſter of the daintieſt Diſh he brings to him; beſeech you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Y'are a bold Miſchief, and to make me your Spokes-man; your procurer to my Servant.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Do you ſhrink at that? why, you have done worſe without the ſenſe of ill, with a full free conſcience of a Libertine: Judge your own ſin, was it not worſe with a damn'd Broking-fee to a corrupt Husband, ſtate him a Pandor to his own wife, by vertue of a Leaſe made to him and your Baſtard iſſue, could you get 'em: what a degree of baſeneſs call you this? 'Tis a poor Sheep-ſteal provok'd by want, compar'd unto a Capital Traitor; the Maſter to his ſervant may be recompenc't, but the husband to his wife never.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your husband ſhall ſmart for this.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: Hang him, do, you have brought him to deſerve it, bring him to the puniſhment, there I'le joyn with you: I loath him to the Gallowes, hang your Page too, one Mourning-Gown ſhall ſerve for both of them: This trick hath kept mine honeſty ſecure, beſt Soldiers uſe policy, the Lions skin Becomes not the body when 'tis too great, But then the Foxes may ſit cloſe, and neat.

div.stage: Enter Fleſh-hook, Counter-buff, and Sweetball the Barber.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Now Fleſh-hook, uſe thy talon, ſet upon his right ſhoulder; thy Sergeant Counter-buff at the left, graſp in his Jugulars, and then let me alone to tickle his Diaphragma.

sp.speaker: Fleſh.
sp.p: You are ſure he has no protection, ſir?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: A protection to cheat and cozen! there was never any granted to that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fleſh.
sp.p: I grant you that too, ſir, but that uſe has hin made of 'em.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Marry has there ſir, how could elſe ſo many broken Bankrupts play up and down by their Creditors noſes, and we dare not touch 'em?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p:
That's another Caſe, Counter buff, there's priviledge to cozen; but here cozenage went before, and there's no priviledge
for that; to him boldly, I will ſpend all the Sizzars in my ſhop, but I'le have him ſnapt.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Well ſir, if he come within the length of large Mace once, wee'l teach him to cozen.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Marry hang him, teach him no more cozenage, he's too perfect in't already; go gingerly about it, lay your Mace on gingerly, and ſpice him ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: He's at the Tavern, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: At the Man in the Moon, above ſtairs, ſo ſoon as he comes down, and the Buſh left at his back, Ralph is the dog behinde him: he watches to give us notice, be ready then my dear Blood-hounds, you ſhall deliver him to Newgate, from thence to the Hang-man; his body I will beg of the Sheriffs, for at the next Lecture I am likely to be the Maſter of my Anatomy, then will I vex every vein about him, I will finde where his Diſeaſe of Cozenage lay, whether in the Vertebrae, or in Oſcox▪Index, but I gueſs I ſhall finde it deſcend from Humore, through the Thoric, and lye juſt at his fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Be in readineſs, for hee's coming this way, alone too; ſtand to't like Gentleman and Yeoman, ſo ſoon as he is in ſight, I'le go fetch my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I have had a Conquaſsition in my Cerebrum ever ſince the diſaſter, and now it takes me agen, if it turn to a Megrum, I ſhall hardly abide the ſight of him.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: My Action of Defamation ſhall be clapt on him too, I will make him appear to't in the ſhape of a white Sheet all embroidered over with Peccavi's: look about, I'le go fetch my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: I Arreſt you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha qui va la, que penſes vous faire Meſſieurs, me voles vous derober, ie nay point d'argent: Je ſuis vn pouure Gentilhomme Francois.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Whoop! pray you ſir ſpeak Engliſh you did when you bought Cloth of Gold at ſix Nihils a yard, when Ralphs Preputium was exulcerated.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Que voules vous, me voules vous tuer; Le Francois ne ſont point enemis: voila ma bource, que voles vous d'avantage.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Is not your name Franklin, ſir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Je na'y point de Joiaux que ceſtui ci; et ceſt a Monſieur L'ambaſadeur, il m'en voie a ces afaires et vous enpaiches mon ſervice.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Sir, we are miſtaken for ought I perceive.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: So, ſo, you have caught him, that's well: how do you ſir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Vous ſembles eſtre vn homme courtois, Je vous prie entendes mes affaires: il y a ici deux ou erois Quenailles qui m'ont aſſeige vn pouure eſtranger, qui ne leur ay fait nul mal, ny donner mauuaiſſe parrolle, ny tirer mon eſpet; l'un me prend par vne eſpaule, et me frape deux Liure peiſant; L'autre me tire par le bras, il par le ie ne ſcay quoy: Je leur ay donne ma bource, et ſi ne me veuleut point Laiſer aller; que feray ie Monſieur?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This is a French-man it ſeems, ſirs.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: We can finde no other in him, ſir, and what that is we know not.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: He's very like the man we ſeek for, elſe my lights go falſe.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: In your ſhop they may ſir, but here they go true: this is he.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The very ſame ſir, as ſure as I am Ralph, this is the Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Sir, unleſs you will abſolutely challenge him the man, we dare not proceed further.

sp.speaker: Fleſh.
sp.p: I fear we are too far already.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to't.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Bon iour, bon iour, Gentilhommes.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: How now! more News from France?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ceſte femme ici eſt de mon pais, Madame ie vous prie Leur dire mon pais, il mont retarge Je ne ſcay pour quoy.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Eſtes vous de France Monſieur?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Madame vay eſt, que ie les ay trompes, et ſuis areſte, et n'ay nul moien de chaper quan chanſant mon Language▪ aides moy en ceſt affaire: Je vous cognois bien, ou vous tenes vn Bordeau; vous et les voſtre en ſeres de mieulx.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Laiſes faire a moy; Eſte vous de Lion dites vous.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: De Lion, ma chere Damme.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ma Cozin! Je ſuis bien aiſe de vous voire en bonne diſpoſition?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Man Cozin!

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: This is a French-man ſure.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p:
If he be, 'tis the likeſt an Engliſh-man that ever I ſaw, all
his dimenſions, proportions! had I but the diſſecting of his heart, in capſula cordis, could I finde it now; for a French-mans heart is more quaſſitive and ſubject to tremor, then an Engliſh-mans.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Stay, wee'l further enquire of this Gentlewoman. Miſtriſs, if you have ſo much Engliſh to help us with (as I think you have, for I have long ſeen you about London) pray tell us, and truly tell us, Is this Gentleman a natural French-man, or no?

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ey begar, de French-man, borne a Lyon, my Cozin.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Your Couſin? if he be not your Couſin, he's my Couſin, ſure.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ey konoſhe his Pere, what you call his Fadre? he ſell Poiſons.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Sell poiſons, his father was a Potycarry then.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No, no, Poiſons, what you call, Fiſh, fiſh?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Oh, he was a Fiſhmonger.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Ouy, ouy.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Well, well, we are miſtaken I ſee, pray you ſo tell him, and requeſt him not to be offended; an honeſt man may look like a knave, and be ne're the worſe for't, the error was in our eyes, and now we finde it in his tongue.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Je ſaieray encore vne fois Monſieur Cozin, pour voſtre ſauuete, ales vous en; voſtre Liberte eſt ſufiſant: Je gaineray le reſte pour mon devoir, et vous aures voſtre part a mon Eſcole: J'ay vne fillie qui parle vn peu Francois, elle converſera avec vous a la Fleur de Lice en Turnbull-ſtreet: Mon Cozin aies ſoin de vous meſme, et trompes ces Ignorans.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Cozin pour L'amour de vous, et principallement pour moy, ie ſuis content de m'en aller, Je trouueray voſtre Eſcole, et ſi voz Eſcoliers me ſont agreable, ie tireray a L'eſpe' ſeule, et ſi d'auenture ie le rompe, Je paiera diz ſouls et pour ce vieulx Foll, ee ce deux Quenailles, ce Poullens Snip ſnap, et L'autre bonnet rond, Je les voiray pendre premier que ie les voie.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſhe has got him off; but I perceive much anger in his countenance ſtill: and what ſays he, Madam?

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p: Mooſh, mooſh anger, but ey conoſh heere Lodging, ſhall coole him very well, Dere is a Kinſe-womans can mooſh allay heere heat and heere ſpleene, ſhe ſhall do for my ſaka, and he no trobla you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Look, there is earneſt, but thy reward's behinde: Come to my ſhop, the Holy Lamb in Lombard-ſtreet, thou haſt one friend more then e're thou hadſt.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p:
Tanck u Monſieur, ſhall viſit u: ey make all paciſie:
a voſtre ſervice treſhumbement, tree, four, five fool of u.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: What's to be done now?

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: To pay us for our pains ſir, and better reward us, that we may be provided againſt further danger that may come upon's for falſe impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: All goes falſe I think: what do you neighbor Sweetball?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I muſt Phlebotomize ſir, but my Almanack ſays the Sign is in Taurus; I dare not cut my own throat, but if I finde any preſident that ever Barber hang'd himſelf, Ile be the ſecond example.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: This was your ill Luxinium, Barber, to cauſe all to be cheated.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: What ſay you to us, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Good friends, come to me at a calmer hour, my ſorrows lye in heaps upon me now; what you have, keep, if further trouble follow Ile take it on me; I would be preſt to death.

sp.speaker: Counterb.
sp.p: Well ſir, for this time we'l leave you.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I will go with you, Officers, I will walk with you in the open ſtreet though it be a ſcandal to me; for now I have no care of my credit, a Cacokenny is run all over me.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: What ſhall we do now, Ralph?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Faith I know not, ſir: here comes George, it may be he can tell you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: And there I look for more diſaſter ſtill, yet George appeares in a ſmiling countenance. Ralph, home to the ſhop, leave George and I together.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I am gone, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Now George, what better News Eaſtward? all goes ill to'ther way.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I bring you the beſt news that ever came about your ears in your life, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thou putſt me in good comfort, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My Miſtriſs, your wife, will never trouble you more.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Ha? never trouble me more: of this, George, may be made a ſad conſtruction, that phraſe we ſometimes uſe when death makes the ſeparation, I hope it is not ſo with her, George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No ſir, but ſhe vows ſhe 'l never come home agen to you, ſo you ſhall live quietly, and this I took to be very good news, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
The worſt that could be this, candid poiſon; I love her, George, and I am bound to do ſo, the tongues bitterneſs muſt not ſeparate the united ſouls: 'twere baſe and cowardly for all to yield
to the ſmall Tongues aſſault: the whole building muſt not be taken down, for the repairing of a broken window.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I but this is a Principal, ſir: the truth is, ſhe will be divorc't, ſhe ſays, and is laboring with her Couſin Knave (what do you call him?) I have forgotten the latter end of his name.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Knaves-bee, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I Knave, or Knaves-bee, one I took it to be.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Why neither rage, nor envy, can make a cauſe, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes ſir, not onely at your perſon, but ſhe ſhoots at your ſhop too, ſhe ſays you vent Ware that is not warrantable, brayded Ware, and that you give not London meaſure: women you know look for more then a bare yard: and then you keep children in the name of your own, which ſhe ſuſpects came not in at the right door

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: She may as well ſuſpect immaculate Truth to be curſed Falſhood.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I but if ſhe will, ſhe will, ſhe's a woman ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: 'Tis moſt true, George: well, that ſhall be redreſt, my Couſin Creſsingham muſt yield me pardon, the children ſhall home agen, and thou ſhalt conduct 'em, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: That done, Ile be bold to venter once more for her recovery, ſince you cannot live at liberty; but becauſe you are a rich Citizen, you will have your Chain about your neck; I think I have a device will bring you together bi'th years agen, and then look to 'em as well as you can.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Oh George, amongſt all my heavy Troubles, this is the groaning weight; but reſtore my Wife.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Although you ne're lead hour of quiet life.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I will endeavor't George, I'le lend her Will A power and rule to keep all huſht and ſtill; Eat we all Sweet-meats we are ſooneſt rotten.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: A Sentence! pity 't ſhould have bin forgotten. Exeunt.

div.head: ACTUS IV.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Creſſingham, and a Surveyor.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: WHere's Mr. Steward?

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Within: what are you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Surveyor, ſir.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p:
And an Almanack-maker, I take it: Can you tell me what foul weather
is toward?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Marry the fowleſt weather is, that your Land is flying away.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: A moſt terrible prognoſtication! All the reſort, all the buſineſs to my houſe is to my Lady and Mr. Steward; whileſt Sir Francis ſtands for a Cypher: I have made away my ſelf and my power, as if I had done it by Deed of Gift: here comes the Comptroller of the Game.

sp.speaker: Saunder.
sp.p: What, are you yet reſolved to tranſlate this unneceſſary Land into ready money?

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Tranſlate it?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Conveyances are drawn, and the money ready: my Lady ſent me to you, to know directly if you meant to go through in the Sale; if not, ſhe reſolves of another courſe.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt this cheerfully methinks, whereas faithful ſervants were wont to mourn when they beheld the Lord that fed and cheriſht them, is by curſt inchantment remov'd into another blood. Creſsingham of Creſsingham has continued many years, and muſt the Name ſink now?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: All this is nothing to my Ladies reſolution, it muſt be done, or ſhe'l not ſtay in England: ſhe would know whether your ſon be ſent for, that muſt likewiſe ſet his hand t'oth' Sale; for otherwiſe the Lawyers ſay there cannot be a ſure Conveyance made to the Buyer.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſent for him: but I pray thee think what a hard task 't will be for a Father to perſwade his ſon and heir to make away his inheritance.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Nay for that, uſe your own Logick: I have heard you talk at the Seſſions terribly againſt Deer-ſtealers, and that kept you from being put out of the Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: I do live to ſee two miſeries, one to be commanded by my Wife, the other to be cenſured by my ſlave.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: That which I have wanted long, and has bin cauſe of my irregular courſes, I beſeech you let raiſe me from the ground

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Riſe George, there's a hundred pounds for you, and my Bleſſing, with theſe, your mothers favor: but I here your ſtudies are become too licentious of late.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: H'as heard of my cozenage.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: What's that you are writing?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Sir, not any thing.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p:
Come, I hear there's ſomething coming
forth of yours, will be your undoing.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Of mine?

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Yes of your writing; ſomewhat you ſhould write, will be dangerous to you. I have a ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Sir, my obedience makes you commander in all things.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: I pray ſuppoſe I had committed ſome fault, for which my Life and ſole Eſtate were forfeit to the Law, and that ſome great Man neer the King ſhould labor to get my pardon, on condition he might enjoy my Lordſhip, could you prize your Fathers Life above the grievous loſs of your inheritance?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Yes, and my own Life at ſtake too.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: You promiſe fair, I come now to make trial of it: You know I have married one whom I hold ſo dear, that my whole life is nothing but a meer eſtate depending upon her will, and her affections to me: ſhe deſerves ſo well, I cannot longer merit then durante bene placita, 'tis her pleaſure, and (her wiſdom moves in't too) of which Ile give you ample ſatisfaction hereafter, that I ſell the Land my Father left me: You change colour! I have promis'd her to do't, and ſhould I fail, I muſt expect the remainder of my life as full of trouble and vexation, as the Suit for a Divorce; it lies in you by ſetting of your hand unto the Sale, to add length to his life that gave you yours.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p:
Sir, I do now ingeniouſly perceive why you ſaid lately, ſomewhat I ſhould write would be my undoing, meaning (as I take it) ſetting my hand to this Aſſurance: Oh good Sir, ſhall I paſs away my Birth-right? Oh remember there is a malediction denounc't againſt it in Holy Writ: will you for her pleaſure, the Inheritance of Deſolation leave to your poſterity? think how compaſſionate the creatures of the field that onely live on the wilde benefits of Nature, are unto their yong ones; think likewiſe you may have more children by this woman, and by this act you undo them too: 'tis a ſtrange preſident this, to ſee an obedient ſon laboring good counſel to the father! But know Sir, that the ſpirits of my Great-Grandfather and your Father moves at this preſent in me, and what they bequeath'd you, on your Death-bed they charge you not to give away in the dalliance of a womans bed: Good Sir, let it not be thought preſumption in me, that I have continued my ſpeech unto this length, the cauſe ſir, is urgent, and believe it you ſhall finde her Beauty as malevolent unto you, as a red morning
that doth ſtill foretel a foul day to follow: Oh Sir, keep your Land, keep that to keep your Name immortal, and you ſhall ſee All that her Malice and proud Will procures,
Shall ſhew her ugly heart, but hurt not yours.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Oh I am diſtracted, and my very ſoul ſends bluſhes into my cheeks.
sp.stage: Enter George with the two Children.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: See here an Object to beget more compaſſion.

sp.speaker: George.
