sp.p: O Sir Francis, we have a moſt lamentable houſe at home, nothing to be heard in't but Separation and Divorces, and ſuch a noiſe of the Spiritual Court, as if it were a Tenement upon London-Bridge, and built upon the Arches.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: All about Boarding your children, my Miſtriſs is departed. Creſſ. Dead?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: In a ſort ſhe is, and laid out too, for ſhe is run away from my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Seven miles off, into Eſſex, ſhe vowd never to leave Barking while ſhe liv'd, till theſe were brought home agen.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Oh they ſhall not offend her. I am ſorry for't.

sp.speaker: 1 Childe.
sp.p: I am glad we are come home ſir, for we liv'd in the unquieteſt houſe!

sp.speaker: 2 Childe.
sp.p: The angry woman me thought grutcht us our victuals: our new Mother is a good Soul, and loves us, and does not frown ſo like a Vixen as ſhe does.

sp.speaker: 1 Childe.
sp.p: I am at home now, and in heaven me thinks: what a comfort 'tis to be under your wing!

sp.speaker: 2 Childe.
sp.p: Indeed my mother was wont to call me your Neſtlecock, and I love you as well as ſhe did.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: You are my pretty ſouls.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Does not the prattle of theſe move you?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Look you Sir, here's the Conveyance and my Ladies Solicitor, pray reſolve what to do, my Lady is coming down. How now George, how does thy Miſtriſs that ſits in a Wainſcot Gown, like a Citizens Lure to draw in Cuſtomers? oh ſhe's a pretty Mouſtrap!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: She's ill baited though to take a Welch-man, ſhe cannot away with Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: And what muſt I do now?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Acknowledge a Fine and Recovery of the Land, then for poſſeſſion the courſe is common.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p:
Carry back the Writings ſir, my minde is
chang'd.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Chang'd! do not you mean to ſeal?

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: No Sir, the Tide's turn'd.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: You muſt temper him like wax, or he'l not ſeal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are you come back again? How now, have you done?

sp.speaker: 1 Childe.
sp.p: How do you, Lady Mother?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are good children; bid my woman give them ſome Sweet-meats.

sp.speaker: 1 Childe.
sp.p: Indeed I thank you: Is not this a kinde Mother?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Poor fools, you know not how dear you ſhall pay for this Sugar.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What, han't you diſpatcht?

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: No Sweeteſt, I am diſſwaded by my ſon from the Sale o'th Land.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Diſſwaded by your ſon!

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: I cannot get his hand to't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where's our Steward? cauſe preſently that all my Beds and Hangings be taken down; provide Carts, pack them up, I'le to my Houſe i'th Countrey, have I ſtudied the way to your preferment and your childrens, and do you cool i'th upſhot?

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: With your pardon, I cannot underſtand this courſe a way to any preferment, rather a direct path to our ruine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh ſir, you are young ſighted: ſhew them the project of the Land I mean to buy in Ireland, that ſhall out-value yours three thouſand in a year.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Look you ſir, here is Clangibbon, a fruitful countrey, and well wooded.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: What's this, Marſh ground?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No, theſe are Boggs, but a little Coſt will drain them. This upper part (Map▪ that runs by the black water, is the Coſſacks Land, a ſpacious countrey, and yields excellent profit by the Salmon, and fiſhing for Herring: here runs the Kernes-dale, admirable feed for cattel, and here about is St. Patrick's Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Purgatory! ſhall we purchaſe that too?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, come, will you diſpatch th'other buſineſs, we may go through with this?

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: My ſon's unwilling.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul ſir, I'le never bed with you till you have ſeal'd.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Thou hear'ſt her: on thy bleſſing follow me to'th' Court, and ſeal.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Sir, were it my death, wer't to'th' loſs of my eſtate, I vow to obey you in all things; yet with it remember there are two young ones living that may curſe you: I pray diſpoſe part of the money, on their generous Educations.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Fear no you ſir: The Caroche there, when you have diſpatcht, you ſhall finde
me at the Scriveners where I ſhall receive the money.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: She'l devour that maſs too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How likeſt thou my power over him?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is the height of a great Ladies ſway,
When her night ſervice makes her rule i'th day.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Not yet Sib? my Lord keeps thee ſo long, th'art welcome I ſee then, and pays ſweetly too: a good wench Sib th'art, to obey thy husband. She's come: a hundred mark a year, how fine and eaſie it comes into mine arms now! Welcome home, what ſays my Lord, Sib?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My Lord ſays you are a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, I thank him for that Bob ifaith, Ile afford it him again at the ſame price a moneth hence, and let the comodity grow as ſcarce as it will. Cuckold ſays his Lordſhip! ha, ha, I ſhall burſt my ſides with laughing that's the worſt, name not a hundred year, for then I burſt. It ſmarts not ſo much as a fillip on the forehead by five parts: what has his dalliance taken from thy lips? 'tis as ſweet as ere 'twas, let me try elſe: buſs me Sugar-candy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Forbear, you preſume to a Lords pleaſure!

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: How's that! not I Sib?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Never touch me more, Ile keep the noble Stamp upon my lip, no under baſeneſs ſhall deface it now; you taught me the way, now I am in, Ile keep it, I have kiſt Ambition, and I love it, I loath the memory of every touch my lip hath taſted from thee.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay but ſweet Sib, you do forget your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I will forget all that I ever was, and nouriſh new ſirrah, I am a Lady.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Lord bleſs us Madam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have enjoy'd a Lord, that's real poſſeſſion, and daily ſhall, the which all Ladies have not with their Lords.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But with your patience Madam, who was it that prefer'd you to this Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Tis all I am beholding to thee for, th'aſt brought me out of ignorance into light, ſimple as I was, I thought thee a man till I found the difference by a man: thou art a beaſt, a horned beaſt, an Ox.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Are theſe Ladies terms?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: For thy Pandors Fee it ſhall be laid under the Candleſtick, look for't, Ile leave it for thee.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: A little lower, good your Ladyſhip, my Couſin Chamlet is in the houſe, let theſe things go no further.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Tis for mine own credit if I forbear, not thine, thou bugle-browd beaſt thou.
sp.stage: Enter George with Rolls of Paper.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Bidden, bidden, bidden, bidden; ſo, all theſe are paſt: but here's as large a walk to come, if I do not get it up at the feaſt, I ſhall be leaner for bidding the Gueſts I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: How now! who's this?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Doctor Gliſter, et; what word's this? fuxor, oh Uxor, the Doctor and his wife: Mr. Body et uxor of Bow-lane, Mr. Knaves-bee et uxor.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Ha, we are in, what ſoever the matter is.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Here's forty couple more in this quarter; but there the Proviſion bringing in, that puzzels me moſt: One Ox, that will hardly ſerve for Beef too; five Muttons, ten Lambs, poor innocents, they'l be devoured too; three groſs of Capons.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Mercy upon us! what a Slaughter-houſe is here!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Two buſhels of ſmall Birds, Plovers, Snipes, Woodcocks, Partridge, Larks; then for Bak'd-meats.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: George, George, what Feaſt is this? 'tis not for St. George's day?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Cry you mercy ſir, you and your wife are in my Roll: my Maſter invites you his Gueſts to morrow dinner.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Dinner ſayſt thou? he means to feaſt a moneth ſure.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Nay ſir, you make up but a hundred couple.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why, what Ship has brought an India home to him, that he's ſo bountiful? or what friend dead (unknown to us) has ſo much left to him of arrable Land, that he means to turn to paſture thus?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis a veſſel ſir, a good eſtate comes all in one bottom to him, and 'tis a queſtion whether ever he finde the bottom or no; a thouſand a year, that's the uppermoſt.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: A thouſand a year!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: To go no further about the Buſh ſir, now the Bird is caught; my Maſter is to morrow to be married, and amongſt the reſt invites you a Gueſt, at his Wedding-Dinner the ſecond.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: There is no other remedy for fleſh and blood, that will have leave to play whether we will or no, or wander into forbidden paſtures.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Married! why he is married, man; his wife is in my houſe now, thy Miſtriſs is alive, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: She that was, it may be ſir, but dead to him, ſhe plaid a little too rough with him, and he has diſcarded her, he's divorc'd ſir.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: He divorc'd! then is her labor ſav'd; for ſhe was laboring a Divorce from him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: They are well parted then ſir.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: But wilt thou not ſpeak with her? 'ifaith invite her to 't.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: 'Tis not in my Commiſſion, I dare not, fare you well ſir, I have much buſineſs in hand, and the time is ſhort.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay but George, I prithee ſtay, may I report this to her for a certain truth?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Wherefore am I employ'd in this Invitation ſir?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Prithee what is ſhe, his ſecond Choice?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Truly a goodly preſence, likely to bear great children, and great ſtore, ſhe never ſaw five and thirty Summers together in her life by her appearance, and comes in her French-hood, by my fecks a great Match 'tis like to be; I am ſorry for my old Miſtriſs but cannot help it: pray you excuſe me now ſir, for all the buſineſs goes through my hands, none employ'd but my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why here is news that no man will believe, but he that ſees.

sp.speaker: Kna. Wife.
sp.p: This, and your Cuckoldry, will be digeſtion throughout the City dinners and ſuppers, for a moneth together, there will need no Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: No more of that Sib: Ile call my Couſin Chamlet, and make her partaker of this ſport; ſhe's come already. Couſin, take't at once, y'are a free woman, your late husband's to be married to morrow.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: Married! to whom?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: To a French-hood birlakins, as I underſtand, great chear prepar'd, and great Gueſts invited, ſo far I know.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: What a curſt wretch was I to pare my Nails to day, a Fryday too; I lookt for ſome miſchief.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why, I did think this had accorded with your beſt liking, you ſought for him what he has ſonght for you, a Separation, and by Divorce too.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: Ile Divorce 'em? Is he to be married to a French-hood? I'le dreſs it the Engliſh faſhion; ne're a Coach to be had with ſix horſes to ſtrike fire i'th ſtreets as we go?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Will you go home then?

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: Good Couſin, help me to whet one of my knives, while I ſharp the t'other, give me a ſowr apple to ſet my teeth an edge, I would give five pound for the paring of my nails agen: have you ere a Bird-ſpit i'th' houſe, I'le dreſs one diſh to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: This violence hurts your ſelf the moſt.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: I care not who I hurt; oh my heart, how it beats a both ſides; will you run with me for a wager into Lombard-ſtreet now?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I'le walk with you Couſin a ſufficient pace; Sib. ſhall come ſoftly after, I'le bring you thorough Bearbinder-lane.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p:
Bearbinder-lane cannot hold me, I'le the neereſt way
over St. Mildreds Church, if I meet any French-hoods by the way, I'le make black patches enow for the rhume.

sp.speaker: Kna. wife.
sp.l: So 'tis to my wiſh, Maſter Knavesbee,
Help to make peace abroad, here you'l finde wars,
I'le have a divorce too, with locks and bars.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Madam, but ſtay here a little, my Maſter comes inſtantly, I heard him ſay he did ow you a good turn, and now's the time to take it, Ile warrant you a ſound reward e're you go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ey Tank u de bon cour Monſieur.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Look he's here already, now would a skilful Navigator take in his Sails, for ſure there is a ſtorm towards.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Oh Madam I perceive in your countenance (I am beholding to you) All is peace? Mar. All quiet, goor frendſheep, ey mooch a doe, ey ſtriue wid him: give goor worda for you; no more ſpeak a de matra, all es undonne u no more trobla.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Look, there's the price of a fair pair of Gloves, and wear 'em for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, my hearts broke out of my ribbes.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Nay a little patience.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ey tank u artely, ſhall no beſtowe en gloves, ſhall put mooſh more to dees, an beſtowe your ſhop; Regarde dees ſtofa my pettycote u no ſooſh anodre; ſhall deal wid u for mooſh; take in your hand.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I ſee it Miſtreſs, 'tis good ſtuff indeed, 'tis a Silk raſh, I can pattern it.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Shall he take up her coats before my face? Oh beaſtly creature; French-hood, Frenchhood, I will make your hair grow thorough.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My wife returned! oh welcome home, ſweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: I forbid the Banes, Letcher and ſtrumpet, thou ſhalt bear children without noſes.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: O pardonne moy, by my trat ey meane u no hurta: wat u meant by dees?

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: I will have thine eyes out, and thy Baſtards ſhall be as blinde as Puppies.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sweet Rachel, good Couſin help to pacifie.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: I forbid the Banes, Adulterer.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: What means ſhe by that ſir?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Good Couſin forbid your rage a while, unleſs you hear, by what ſenſe will you receive ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: Mris Cham
sp.p:
By my hands and my teeth
ſir, give me leave, will you binde me whiles mine enemy kills me?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Here all are your friends ſweet wife.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Wil't have two wives? Do and by hang'd Fornicator, I forbid the Banes; give me the French-hood, I'le tread it under feet in a pair of Pantophles.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Begar ſhall ſave hood head and all; ſhall come no more heer, ey warran u.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Sir, the truth is, Report ſpoke it for truth, you were to morrow to be married.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: I forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Mercy deliver me, if my grave imbrace me in the bed of death, I would to Church with willing ceremony; but for my wedlock-fellow, here ſhe is the firſt and laſt that ere my thoughts lookt on.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Why law you Couſin, this was nought but error or an aſſault of miſchief.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Whoſe report was it?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Your man Georges, who invited me to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: George? And was he ſober? Good ſir call him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: It needs not ſir, I am here already.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Did you report this George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes ſir I did.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: And wherefore did you ſo?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: For a new ſute that you promiſt me ſir, if I could bring home my Miſtreſs, and I think ſhe's come with a miſchief.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Give me that villaines ears.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I would give ear, if I could hear you talk wiſely.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Let me cut off his ears.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I ſhall hear worſe of you hereafter then, limb for limb, one of my ears, for one of your tongues, and Ile lay out for my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: 'Twas knavery with a good purpoſe in't, ſweet Rachel, this was e'en Georges meaning, a ſecond marriage 'twixt thy ſelf and me, and now I wooe the to't, a quiet night will make the Sun like a freſh Bridegroom riſe, and kiſs the chaſt echeek of the roſy morn which we will imitate, and like him creat Freſh buds of love, freſh ſpreading arms, freſh fruit, Freſh wedding robes, and Georges freſh new ſute.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: This is fine ſtuff, have you much on't to ſell?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: A remnant of a yard.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Come, come, all's well, ſir, you muſt ſup, inſtead of to morrows dinner.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.l: I follow you; no: 'tis another way,
My Lords reward calls me to better cheer
Many good meals a hundred markes a yeer;
my wifes transform'd a Lady, tuſh, ſhee'l come to her ſhape agen,
my Lord rides the circuit,
If I rid along with him, what need I grutch
I can as eaſie ſit, and ſpeed as much.

div.head: ACTUS. V.
div.stage: Enter old Francklin in mourning: young Creſſingham with young Francklin diſguiſ'd like an old Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: SIr, your ſons death which has apparrel'd you in this darker wearing, is a loſs wherein I have ample ſhare; he was my friend.

sp.speaker: Old Fran.
sp.p: He was my neereſt and deereſt enemy, and the perpetual fear of a worſe end had he continued his former diſſolute courſe, makes me weigh his death the lighter.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: Yet ſir, with your pardon, if you value him every way as he deſerv'd, it will appear your ſcanting of his means, and the Lord Beauforts moſt un-lordly breach of promiſe to him, made him fall upon ſome courſes, to which his nature and mine own, (made deſperate likewiſe by the cruelty of a Mother in Law) would elſe have bin as ſtrange, as inſolent greatneſs is to diſtreſs'd vertue.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Yes, I have heard of that too; your defeat made upon a Mercer, I ſtyle't modeſtly, the Law intends it plain cozenage.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p: 'Twas no leſs, but my penitence and reſtitution, may come fairly off from't; it was no Impeachment to the Glory won at Agencourts great Battel, that the Atchiever of it in his youth had bin a Purſe-taker, this with all reverence to'th great Example. Now to my buſineſs, wherein you have made ſuch noble tryal of your worth, that in a world ſo dull as this, where faith is almoſt grown to be a miracle, I have found a friend ſo worthy as your ſelf, to purchaſe all the Land my Father ſold at the perſwaſion of a riotous woman, and charitable to reſerve it for his uſe, and the good of his three children; this I ſay, is ſuch a deed ſhall ſtyle you our Preſerver, and ow the memory of your worth, and pay it to all poſterity.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Sir, what I have done, looks to the end of the good deed it ſelf, no other way i'th world.

sp.speaker: Yong Creſſ.
sp.p:
But would you pleaſe out of a friendly reprehenſion,
to make him ſenſible of the weighty wrong he has done his children, yet I would not have it too bitter, for he undergoes already ſuch torment in a womans naughty pride, too harſh reproof would kill him.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Leave you that to my diſcretion: I have made my ſelf my ſons Executor, and am come up on purpoſe to collect his Creditors, and where I finde his pennyworth conſcionable, Ile make them in part ſatisfaction:
Oh this fellow was born neer me, and his trading here i'th City may bring me to the knowledge of the men my ſon ought money to.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Your Worſhip's welcome to London, and I pray how does all our good friends i'th Countrey?

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: They are well, George: how thou art ſhot up ſince I ſaw thee? what, I think thou art almoſt out of thy Time?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I am out of my wits ſir, I have liv'd in a kinde of Bedlam theſe four years, how can I be mine own man then?

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I may turn Soap-boyler, I have a looſe body: I am turn'd away from my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: How! turn'd away! Indenture.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I am gone ſir, not in drink, and yet you may behold my Indentures: Oh the wicked wit of woman, for the good turn I did bringing her home, ſhe ne're left ſucking my Maſters breath, like a Cat, kiſſing him I mean, till I was turn'd away!

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: I have heard ſhe's a terrible woman.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, and the miſerableſt! her ſparing in Houſe-keeping has coſt him ſomewhat, the Dagger-pyes can teſtifie: ſhe has ſtood in's light moſt miſerably, like your Faſting-days before Red letters in the Almanack: ſaying, the pinching of our bellies would be a mean to make him wear Scarlet the ſooner. She had once perſwaded him to have bought Spectacles for all his ſervants, that they might have worn 'em dinner and ſupper.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: To what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Marry, to have made our Victuals ſeem bigger than 't was: ſhe ſhews from whence ſhe came, that my Winde-collick can witneſs.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Why, whence came ſhe?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Marry from a Courtier, and an Officer too, that was up and down I know not how often.

sp.speaker: Old. Fra.
sp.p: Had he any great place?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, and a very high one, but he got little by it; he was one that blew the Organ in the Court Chappel, our Puritans, eſpecially your Puritans in Scotland, could ne're away with him.

sp.speaker: Old. Fran.
sp.p: Is ſhe one of the Sect?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Faith I think not,
for I am certain, ſhe denies her husband the ſupremacy.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Well George, your difference may be reconcil'd. I am now to uſe your help in a buſineſs that concerns me: here's a Note of mens names here i'th' City, unto whom my ſon ought money, but I do not know their dwelling?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Let me ſee ſir: fifty pound ta'ne up at uſe of Mr. Water Thin the Brewer.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: An obſtinat fellow, and one that deni'd payment of the groats, till he lay by'th' heels for't; I know him: Item, fourſcore pair of provant Breeches'ath' new faſhion, to Pinch buttock a Hoſier in Burchen-lane, ſo much.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: What the devil did he with ſo many pair of breeches?

sp.speaker: Yo. Fran.
sp.p: Supply a Captain ſir, a friend of his went over to the Palatinate.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Item, to my Tailor Mr. Wetherwiſe, by St. Clements-church.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Who ſhould that be? it may be 'tis the new Prophet, the Aſtrological Tailor.

sp.speaker: Yo. Frank.
sp.p: No, no, no ſir, we have nothing to do with him.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Well, I'le read no further, leave the note to my diſcretion, do not fear but I'le enquire them all.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Why, I thank thee.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Sir, reſt aſſur'd I ſhall in all your buſineſs be faithful to you, and at better leiſure finde time to imprint deeply in your father, the wrong he has done you,
sp.stage: Exeunt. Old Franklin, George, and Young Francklin.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: You are worthy in all things?
Is my father ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, my Lady wonders you are thus chargeable to your father, and will not direct your ſelf unto ſome gainful ſtudy, may quit him of your dependance.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: What ſtudy?

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Why the Law, that Law that takes up moſt 'ath' wits i'th kingdom, not for moſt good, but moſt gain, or Divinity; I have heard you talk well, and I do not think but you'd prove a ſingular fine Church-man.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: I ſhould prove a plural better, if I could attain to fine benifices.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: My Lady now ſhe has money, is ſtudying to do good works, ſhe talk'd laſt night what a goodly act it was, of a Counteſs (Northampton-ſhire breed belike, or thereabouts) that to make Coventry a Corporation, rode through the City naked, and by day light.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: I do not think, but you have Ladies living would diſcover as much in private, to advance but ſome member of a Corporation.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p:
Well ſir, your wit is ſtill goaring at my Ladies projects:
here's your father.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: Thou comſt to chide me, hearing how like a ward I am handled, ſince the ſale of my Land.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: No ſir, but to turn your eyes into your own boſom.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: Why, I am become my wives penſioner; am confin'd to a hundred mark a year, t'one ſute, and one man to attend me.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: And is not that enough for a private Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: Peace ſirrah, there is nothing but knave ſpeakes in thee, and my two poor children muſt be put forth to prentice.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Ha! to prentice: ſir, I do not come to grieve you, but to ſhew how wretched your eſtate was that you could not come to ſee order, until foul diſorder pointed the way to't, ſo inconſiderate, yet ſo fruitful ſtil is dotage to beget its own deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: Surely I am nothing, and deſire to be ſo, pray thee fellow intreat her onely to be quiet, I have given her all my eſtate on that condition.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes ſir, her Coffers are well lin'd believe me.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: And yet ſhe is not contented; we obſerve the Moon is ne're ſo pleaſant, and ſo clear as when ſhe is at the full.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: You did not uſe my mother with this obſervance, you are like the Frogs, who weary of their quiet King, conſented to the election of the Stork, who in the end devour'd them.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: You may ſee how apt man is to forfeit all his judgement upon the inſtant of his fall.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Look up ſir.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: O my hearts broke; weighty are injuries that come from an enemy, but thoſe are deadly that come from a friend, for Enter the Lady Creſsingham. we ſee commonly thoſe are tane moſt to heart: ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: What a terrible eye ſhe darts on us.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: Oh moſt natural, for lightning to go before the thunder.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What? Are you in councel? are ye levying faction againſt us.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: Good friend.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, ſir, pray come hither, there is winter in your looks, a latter winter, do you complain to your kindred? I'le make you fear extreamly, to ſhew you have any cauſe to fear: Are the bonds ſeal'd for the ſix thouſand pounds I put forth to uſe?

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The bonds were made in my unckles name.

sp.speaker: Saund.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange though.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Nothing ſtrange, you'l think the allowance I have put you to as ſtrange, but your
judgement cannot reach the aim I have in't: you were prickt laſt year to be High Sheriff, and what it would have coſt you I underſtand now, all this charge and the other by the ſale of your Land, and the money at my diſpoſe, and your penſion ſo ſmall, will ſettle you in quiet, make you Maſter of a retir'd life, and our great ones may think you a politique man, and that you are aiming at ſome ſtrange buſineſs, having made all over.

sp.speaker: Old Creſſ.
sp.p: I muſt leave you, man is never truly awake till he be dead.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: What a dream have you made of my father?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let him be ſo, and keep the proper place of dreams; his bed, until I raiſe him.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Raiſe! him not unlikely, 'tis you have ruin'd him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You do not come to quarrel?

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: No certain, but to perſwade you to a thing, that in the vertue of it, nobly carries its own commendation, and you ſhall gain much honor by it, which is the recompence of all vertuous actions, to uſe my father kindly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why? does he complain to you ſir?

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Complain: why ſhould a King complain for any thing, but for his ſins to heaven, the prerogative of husband is like to his, over his wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am full of buſineſs ſir, and will not minde you.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: I muſt not leave you thus; I tell you mother 'tis dangerous to a woman, when her minde raiſes her to ſuch height, it makes her onely capable of her own merit; nothing of duty! oh, 'twas a ſtrange unfortunate o're-priſing your beauty, brought him, (otherwiſe diſcreet) into the fatal neglect of his poor children: what will you give us of the late ſum you receiv'd?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not a penny; away, you are troubleſome and ſawcy.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: You are too cruel: denials even from Princes who may do what they liſt, ſhould be ſupplied with a gratious verbal uſage, that though they do not cure the ſore, they may abate the ſence of't; the wealth you ſeem to command over, is his, and he I hope will diſpoſe of't to our uſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: When he can command my will?

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Have you made him ſo miſerable, that he muſt take a Law from his wife?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Have you not had ſome Lawyers forc't to grone under the burden?

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Oh! but the greater the women, the more viſible are their vices.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
So ſir, you have been ſo bold; by all can
binde an oath, and I'le not break it, I will not be the woman to you hereafter you expected.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Be not; be not your ſelf, be not my fathers wife, be not my Lady Creſsingham, and then I'le thus ſpeak to you, but you muſt not anſwer in your own perſon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A fine Puppet play!

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Good Madam, pleaſe you pity the diſtreſs of a poor Gentleman, that is undone by a cruel Mother in Law, you do not know her, nor does ſhe deſerve the knowledge of any good one, for ſhe does not know her ſelf, you would ſigh for her that ere ſhe took you ſex, if you but heard her qualities.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is a fine Crotchet.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Envy and Pride, flow in her painted breaſts, ſhe gives no other ſuck; all her attendants do not belong to her husband, his money is hers, marry his debts are his own, ſhe bears ſuch ſway, ſhe will not ſuffer his Religion be his own, but what ſhe pleaſe to turn it to.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And all this while, I am the woman you libel againſt.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: I remember e're the Land was ſold, you talkt of going to Ireland, but ſhould you touch there, you would die preſently.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why Man?

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: The country brookes no poiſon: go, You'l finde how difficult a thing it is, to make a ſetled or aſſur'd Eſtate of things ill gotten: when my father's dead, the curſe of Luſt and Riot follow you, marry ſome young gallant that may rifle you; yet add one bleſſing to your needy age, that you may die full of repentance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha, Ha, Ha.

sp.speaker: Ys. Creſſ.
sp.p: Oh! ſhee's loſt to any kinde of goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sirrah, be gone, y'are baſe.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Baſe, my good Lord? 'tis a ground part in Muſick, trebles, means, all his but ſidling, your Honor bore a part as my wife ſays, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your wifes a Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Ah ha, is ſhe ſo? I am glad to hear it, open confeſſion, open payment, the wagers mine then, a hundred a year my Lord, I ſaid ſo before, and ſtak'd my head againſt it, thus after darkſome night, the day is come, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Hence, hide thy branded head, let no day ſee thee, nor thou any but thy execution day.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: That's the day after waſhing day, once a week, I ſee't at home my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
Go home and ſee thy proſtituted wife (for ſure 'tis ſo) now folded in a Boys adultery, my Page; on whom the hot-rain'd harlot doats, this night he hath been her attendant, my houſe he's
fled from, and muſt no more return, go, and make haſte ſir, leſt your reward be loſt for want of looking to.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: My reward loſt; is there nothing due for what is paſt, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes Pander, Wittoll, Macrio, baſeſt of knaves, thou Boulſter-bawd to thine own infamy! go, I have no more about me at this time, when I am better ſtor'd thou ſhalt have more where e're I meet thee.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Pander, Wittoll, Macrio, baſe knave, boulſter bawd; here is but five mark toward a hundred a year: this is poor payment, if Lords may be truſted no better then thus! I will go home and cut my Wifes Noſe off, I will turn over a new Leaf, and hang up the Page; laſtly I will put on a large pair of Wetleather Boots and drown my ſelf, I will ſink at Queen-hive, and riſe agen at Charing-croſs contrary to the Statute in Edwardo primo.

div.stage: Enter Old Franklin; his ſon as before, George, three or four Citizens, Creditors.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Good health to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Mr. Franklin, I heard of your arrival, and the cauſe of this your ſad appearance.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: And 'tis no more then as your Honor ſays, indeed appearance, it has more form then feeling ſorrow Sir, I muſt confeſs, there's none of theſe Gentlemen (though Aliens in blood) but have as large cauſe of grief as I.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: No, by your favor ſir, we are well ſatisfied; there was in his life a greater hope, but leſs aſſurance.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: Sir, I wiſh all my debts of no better promiſe to pay me thus, fifty in the hundred comes fairly homewards.

sp.speaker: Yong Frank.
sp.p: Conſidering hard Bargains and dead Commodities, ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: Thou ſayſt true, friend, and from a dead Debtor too.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And ſo you have compounded and agreed all your ſons riotous Debts?

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: There's behinde but one cauſe of worſe condition, that done, he may ſleep quietly.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: Yes ſure my Lord, this Gentleman is come a wonder to us all, that ſo fairly with half a loſs could ſatisfie thoſe debts were dead, even with his ſon, and from whom we could have nothing claim'd.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: I ſhewed my reaſon; I would have a good name live after him, becauſe he bore my Name.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: May his tongue periſh firſt (and that will ſpoil his trade) that firſt gives him a ſyllable of ill.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why this is friendly.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Mr. Chamlet! very welcome.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Mr. Franklin, I
take it, theſe Gentlemen I know well: good Mr. Pennyſtone, Mr. Phillip, Mr. Cheyney! I am glad I ſhall take my leave of ſo many of my good friends at once; your hand firſt, my Lord, fare you well ſir, nay I muſt have all your hands to my Paſs.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Will you have mine too ſir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Yes, thy two hands George, and I think two honeſt hands of a Tradeſ-man, George, as any between Cornhil and Lombard-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Take heed what you ſay ſir, there's Birchen-lane between 'em.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But what's the cauſe of this, Mr. Chamlet?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I have the cauſe in handling, now my Lord; George, honeſt George is the cauſe, yet no cauſe of Georges, George is turn'd away one way, and I muſt go another.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And whither is your way ſir?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: E'ne to ſeek out a Quiet Life, my Lord: I do hear of a fine peaceable Iſland.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why 'tis the ſame you live in.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: No, 'tis ſo fam'd, but we th'inhabitants finde it not ſo; the place I ſpeak of has bin kept with thunder, with frightful lightnings, amazing Noiſes, but now (th'inchantment broke) 'tis the Land of Peace, where Hogs and Tobacco yield fair increaſe.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is a little wilde methinks.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Gentlemen, fare you well, I am for the Bermudas.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay, good ſir ſtay, and is that your onely cauſe, the loſs of George?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The loſs of George, my Lord! make you that no cauſe? why but examine, would it not break the ſtout heart of a Nobleman to looſe his George, much more the tender boſom of a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Fie, fie, I'm ſorry your gravity ſhould run back to lightneſs thus: you go to the Bermothes!

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Better to Ireland Sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: The Land of Ire, that's too neer home, my wife will be heard from Hellbree to Divellin.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt of neceſſity a while detain you: I muſt acquaint you with a benefit that's coming towards you. You were cheated of ſome goods of late, come, I'm a Cunning-man, and will help you to the moſt part again, or ſome reaſonable ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: That's another cauſe of my unquiet Life, ſir; can you do that, I may chance ſtay another Tide or two: My wife! (I muſt ſpeak more private with you) by forty foot pain of death, I dare not reach her: No words of me ſweet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I had need hide too.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, I have ſcarce tongue enough yet to tell you; my husband, my husband's gone from me, your warrant good my Lord, I never had ſuch need of your warrant; my husband's gone from me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Going he is, 'tis true; has tane his leave of me, and all theſe Gentlemen, and 'tis your ſharp tongue that whips him forwards.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: A warrant, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You turn away his ſervants, ſuch on whom his eſtate depends he ſays, who know his books, his debts, his cuſtomers; the form and order of all his affairs you make orderleſs, chiefly his George you have baniſht from him.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: My Lord, I will call George agen.

sp.speaker: George within.
sp.p: Call George agen.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why hark you, how high voic'd you are, that raiſe an Eccho from my Selleridge which we with modeſt loudneſs cannot.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: My Lord, do you think I ſpeak too loud?

sp.speaker: George within.
sp.p: Too loud.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why hark, your own tongue anſwers you, and reverberates your words into your teeth.

sp.speaker: Mris. Cham.
sp.p: I will ſpeak lower all the days of my life: I never found the fault in my ſelf till now, your warrant good my Lord, to ſtay my husband.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well, well, it ſhall o'retake him, ere he paſs Graveſend, provided that he meet his quietneſs at home, elſe he's gone agen.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: And withal to call George agen.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: I will call George agen.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Call George agen.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: See, you are raiſed agen, the Eccho tells you.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: I did forget my ſelf indeed, my Lord: this is my laſt fault, I will go make a ſilent enquiry after George, I will whiſper half a ſcore Porters in the ear, that ſhall run ſoftly up and down the City to ſeek him. Bewy ye my Lord, buoy all Gentlemen. Exit

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: George, your way lies before you now, croſs the ſtreet, and come into her eyes, your Maſters Journey will be ſtaid.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Ile warrant you bring it to better ſubjection yet.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Theſe are fine flaſhes: how now Mr. Chamlet?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I had one ear lent to you-ward, my Lord, and this o'th to'ther ſide, both ſounded ſweetly: I have whole recovered my late loſſes ſir, th'one half paid, the to'ther is forgiven.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Then your Journey is ſtaid?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Alas my Lord, that was a trick of age, for I had left never
a trick of youth like it, to ſuccour me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How now? what new Object's here!

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: The next man we meet ſhall judge us.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Content, though he be but a Common-Council-man.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The one's a knave, I could know him at twelve ſcore diſtance.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: And to'ther 's a Barber-Surgeon, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Ile go no further, here is the honorable Lord, that I know will grant my requeſt; My Lord—

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Peace, I will make it plain to his Lordſhip: My Lord, a Covenant by Jus Jurandum is between us, he is to ſuffocate my Reſpiration by his Capiſtrum, and I to make inciſſion ſo far as mortification by his Jugulars.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is not altogether ſo plain neither, ſir.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I can ſpeak no plainer my Lord, unleſs I wrong mine art.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I can my Lord, I know ſome part of the Law, I am to take him in this place where I finde him, and lead him from hence to the place of Execution, and there to hang him till he dies; he in equal courteſie is to cut my throat with his Razor, and there's an end of both on's.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: There is the end my Lord, but we want the beginning: I ſtand upon it to be ſtrangled firſt, before I touch either his Gula or Ceruix.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I am againſt it, for how ſhall I be ſure to have my Throat cut after he's hang'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is this a Condition betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: A firm Covenant, ſign'd and ſeal'd by oath and handfaſt, and wants nothing but Agreement.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: A little pauſe: what might be the cauſe on either part?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: My paſſions are grown to putrifaction, and my griefs are gangren'd; Mr. Chamlet has ſcarified me all over, beſides the loſs of my new Bruſh.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I am kept out of mine own Caſtle, my Wife keeps the Hold againſt me: your Page my Lord, is her Champion; I ſummon'd a Parle at the window, was anſwered with Defiance: they confeſs they have layen together, but what they have done elſe I know not.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Thou canſt have no wrong that deſerves pity, thou art thy ſelf ſo bad.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I thank your Honor for that, let me have my throat cut then.
sp.stage: Enter Selenger as a woman, and Mris Knavesbee.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Sir, I can give you a better remedy then his Capiſtrum; your ear a little.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: I come with a bold innocence to anſwer the beſt and worſt that can accuſe me here.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Your husband.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p:
He's the worſt, I dare his
worſt.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Your Page, your Page.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: We lay together in bed, it is confeſt; you, and your ends of Law makes worſer of it, I did it for reward.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ile hear no more of this, come Gentlemen will you walk?

sp.speaker: Young Creſſ.
sp.p: My Lord, a little ſtay; you'l ſee a ſight that neighbor amity wilbe much pleas'd with, 'tis come already, my Father ſir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: There muſt be cauſe certain for this good change: Sir, you are bravely met, this is at the beſt I ever ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: My Lord, I am amazement to my ſelf; I ſlept in poverty, and am awake into this wonder; how I can thus brave, my dreams did not ſo much as tell me of; I am of my kinde ſons new making up, it exceeds the penſion much, that yeſternight allow'd me, and my pockets centupled, but I am my ſons childe, ſir, he knows of me more then I do my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Young Creſſ.
sp.p: Sir, you yet have but earneſt of your happineſs, a Pinace fore-riding a goodly veſſel, by this near Anchor-bulkt like a Caſtle, and with Jewels fraught, (Joys above Jewels ſir,) from deck to keel, make way for the receipt, empty your boſom of all griefs and troubles, leave not a ſigh to beat her back again, ſhe is ſo ſtor'd ye'ad need have room enough, to take her lading.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: If one Comodity be wanting now, all this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Young Creſſ.
sp.p: Tuſh, that muſt out too, there muſt be no remembrance, not the thought that ever youth in woman did abuſe you, that e're your children had a ſtepmother, that you ſold Lands to pleaſe your puniſhment, that you were circumſcrib'd and taken in, abridg'd the large extendure of your grounds, and put into the pinfold that belong'd to't, that your ſon did cheat for want of maintenance; that he did beg, you ſhall remember onely, for I have beg'd off all theſe troubles from you.

div.stage: Enter Lady Creſſ. in civil habit, Saund. and children very gallant.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This was a good weeks labor.

sp.speaker: Young Creſſ.
sp.p: Not an hours my Lord, but 'twas a happy one; ſee ſir, a new day ſhines on you.

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p: Oh ſir, your ſon has rob'd me.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: Ha! that way I inſtructed?

sp.speaker: Yo Creſſ.
sp.p: Nay, hear her ſir.

sp.speaker: La. Creſſ.
sp.p: Of my good purpoſe ſir, he hath forc'd out of me, what lay conceal'd, ripen'd my pity with his dews of duty, forgive me ſir, and but keep the number of every grief that I have pain'd you with, I'le ten-fold pay with freſh obedience.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Oh, that my wife were here to learn this leſſon.

sp.speaker: Lady Creſſ.
sp.p: Your ſtate is not abated, what was yours, is ſtill your own, and take the cauſe withal of my harſh ſeeming uſage; it was to reclaim faults in your ſelf, the ſwift conſumption of many large revenues, Gaiming, that of not much leſs ſpeed, burning up houſe and land, not caſual but cunning fire, which though it keeps the Chymney, and outward ſhows like Hoſpitality, is onely devourer on't, Conſuming Chymiſtry; there I have made you a flat banquet-out; all your Stillatories and laboring Minerals are demoliſh'd, that part of Hell in your houſe is extinct, put out your deſire with them, and then theſe feet ſhall level with my hands, untill you raiſe my ſtoop'd humility to higher grace, to warm theſe lips with love, and duty do to every ſilver hair, each one ſhal be a Senator to my obedience.

sp.speaker: Creſſ.
sp.p: All this I know before, who ever of you that had but one ill thought of this good woman, you owe a knee to her, and ſhe is merciful if ſhe forgive you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That ſhal be private penance ſir, we'l all joy in publique with you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: On the conditions I tell you, not elſe.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Sweet George, dear George, any conditions.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: My wife!

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Peace, George is bringing her to conditions.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Good ones, good George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You ſhall never talk your voice above the key, ſol, ſol, ſol.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Sol, ſol, ſol, I George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Say welcome home honeſt George, in that pitch.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Welcome home honeſt George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Why this is well now.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: That's well indeed, George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Rogue, nor Raſcal muſt never come out of your mouth.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: They ſhall never come in, honeſt George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Nor I will not have you call my Maſter plain husband, that's too courſe, but as your Gentlewomen in the Country uſe, and your perſons wives in the Town, 'tis comely, and ſhalbe cuſtomed in the City, call him Maſter Chamlet at every word.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: At every word, honeſt George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Look you, there he is, ſalute him then.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: Welcome home, good Mr. Chamlet.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: Thanks, and a thouſand ſweet Wife; I may ſay honeſt George.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Yes ſir, or Bird, or Chuck, or Hearts ease,
or plain Rachel, but call her Rac no more, ſo long as ſhe is quiet.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: God-a-mercy, ſha't have thy new ſute a Sunday George.

sp.speaker: Mris Cham.
sp.p: George ſhall have two new ſutes, Mr. Chamlet.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: God-a-mercy, ifaith Chuck.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Mr. Chamlet, you and I are friends, all even betwixt us?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: I do acquit thee, neighbor Sweetbal.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I will not be hang'd then, Knares-bee do thy worſt; nor I will not cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: I muſt do't my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: If thou com'ſt to my ſhop, and uſurp'ſt my chair of maintenance, I will go as neer as I can, but I will not do't.

sp.speaker: Young Creſſ.
sp.p: No, 'tis I muſt cut Knaves-bees throat, for ſlandering a modeſt Gentlewoman, and my wife in ſhape of your Page, my Lord, in her own I durſt not place her ſo neer your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No more of that ſir, if your ends have acquir'd their own events, crown 'em with your own Joy.

sp.speaker: Yo. Creſſ.
sp.p: Down a your knees Knaves-bee, to your wife, ſhe's too honeſt for you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Down, down, before you are hang'd, 'twilbe to late afterwards, and long thou canſt not ſcape it.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: You'l play the Pandor no more, will you?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Oh, that's an inch into my throat.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: And let out your wife for her?

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.p: Oh ſweet wife, go no deeper.

sp.speaker: Mris. Kna.
sp.p: Dare any be bail for your better behavior?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, yes I dare, he will mend one day.

sp.speaker: Mris Kna.
sp.p: And be worſe the next.

sp.speaker: Kna.
sp.l: Hang me the third then, dear merciful wife,
I will do Any thing for a quiet Life.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: All then is reconcil'd?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Onely my bruſh is loſt, my dear new bruſh.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: I will help you to ſatisfaction for that too ſir.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Oh, Sperma Caete, I feel it heal already.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have fully ſatisfied my dead ſons debts?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All pleas'd, all paid ſir.

sp.speaker: Old Frank.
sp.p:
Then once more here I bring him back to life, from my ſervant to my ſon, nay, wonder not; I have not delt by fallacy with any, my ſon was dead, who e're out lives his vertues is a dead man, for when you hear of ſpirits that walk in real bodies, to the amaze and cold aſtoniſhment of ſuch as meet 'em, and all would ſhun; thoſe are men of vices, who nothing have but what is viſible, and ſo by conſequence they have no ſouls, but if the ſoul return
but if the Soul return he lives agen,
sp.l: Created newly; ſuch my Son appears
By my bleſſing rooted, growing by his tears.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: You have beguil'd us honeſtly ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And you ſhall have your bruſh agen.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: My baſons ſhall all ring for joy

sp.speaker: Beaufort.
sp.p: Why this deſerves a Tryumph, and my coſt ſhall begin a feaſt to't, to which I do envite you all; ſuch happy reconcilements muſt not be paſt without a health of joy,
sp.l: Diſcorded friends atton'd, men and their wives
This hope proclaims your after quiet Lives.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.l: I Am ſent t' enquire your Cenſure, and to know
How you ſtand affected? whither we do owe
Our ſervice to your Favors, or muſt ſtrike
Our Sails (though full of hope) to your diſlike:
How e're be pleas'd to think we purpos'd well,
And from my fellows thus much I muſt tell,
Inſtruct us but in what we went aſtray,
And to redeem it, wee'l take any way.
